This electrostatic mat arrived just in time for several electronics kits I have plans to build. Other than the beautiful blue color, the first thing that caught my attention was how thick and heavy it was. I was not expecting that it was so robust and so thick. Of course, I am very glad that it is.  Ill not repeat all the features in the description.

Quite honestly, I was literally about to purchase an electrostatic mat when this became available to me - probably because of the many electronics kits, deluxe soldering iron station, and numerous other related items I've been buying over the past few months.  My wife will build a digital oscilloscope kit I recently purchased here on Amazon along with several other kits and a multitude of basic components to build things from scratch.

This electrostatic mat is literally a foundation of a learning exercise using sensitive electronics. It is not the least bit fun to build something complex and an unknown part became defective during assembly. Which one?  To truly learn electronics, you really should start at the bottom and be hands on to learn how it all works at the component level.  Today's youth just want to skip the basics, but in doing so, they won't learn much unless you know how resistors, capacitors, inductors, and transistors work. Otherwise, it won't ever become second nature - just theory.  My wife already knows how to build desktop computers, rather well in fact.  So this is the next step now that she's developed a strong interest.

With sensitive components, it only takes one zap of static electricity to ruin something - especially in winter when the air inside is very dry.  I am very glad to have this electrostatic mat just in time to start building some projects so that it will protect the components as she assembles the oscilloscope kit. She needs a visual aid. That is why she will build the oscilloscope first. Maybe with the knowledge I impart, she can become an electrical engineer.  After being widowed 9 years, I realized I needed a much younger healthy wife with no kids. She's a little late to get started in electronics, but not terribly late.
summary: Beautiful Thick Smooth Electrostatic Mat with Two Snaps for Electrode Wrist Wire

reviewText: what I expected

I have collected  flashlights, vintage fountain pens, and pocket knives, as hobbies for many years.  It is always so hard to turn any such items down, because you never know what you might be missing.  ;-)

When I revived a request to review the RT-20 flashlight, I immediately noticed it had a rotating head!  Very cool...so I immediately accepted the offer and hoped the light would be decent.

Well, to my surprise, the RT-20 has turned out to be a lot more flashlight then I had ever expected.  For my uses, this is an amazing little guy that is extremely bright, lasts for very long periods on high (well over an hour with no charge!).  The manufacture says it is good for 220 hours on low.

Oh, did I mention the unit has a rotating head, allowing me to get my light beam exactly where I want it.  That is an important feature around the ranch.

The light is rechargeable (18650 battery) and had 1050 lumen output, which I find to be very bright on high...better than expected.  The beam range is also long at approximately 500 feet.
But what is really cool, is it has a battery indicator light on it, which is a feature I really appreciate.

If the power remaining is indicated by lights:

Green:  75%-100% power remaining
Orange:  30%-70%  power remaining
Red:  Less then 30%

The light has 6 different light modes:
-1.  Turbo
-2.  Low
-3.  Medium
-4.  High
-5.  SOS
-6.  Strobe

The flashlight is rated IPX 8...very impressive.  I am use to IPX 6 and 7's being sent to me at this price.  In case you are not familiar with the IPX rating system, I would like to take a minute to give you a little background, which I think will really open your eyes on items you have been buying.  This cursory understanding of this system, and how it works can prevent you from breaking an item in the future.
For the experienced buyer, please just skip this section.  Thanks.

Luckily, since other reviewers did such a good job explaining the lights mechanics, I will take a couple. I used to explain this, as a small understanding might prevent you from damaging a good piece of equipment.

The information below relates to IP Standards, as it relates to water proof and water resistance of the object.  Just simply, as your number gets higher, so does your water proofing.  You will get the idea when you read the list....

- IPX0  This means its not water resistant at all.
- IPX1  This will protect a device from some water drops that are falling vertically on said device.
- PX2   This will protect your thingy from some water drops when the device is tilted up to and including 15. If you have your device at 16, your device is not protected!
- IPX3  Getting better, you can now spray your gear up to 60 from the top of the device.
- IPX4  Now we are getting somewhere. This will keep yo ish chill from splashing water from any direction.
- IPX5  Protects your stuff from water jets at any direction. Even kids super soakers!
- IPX6  Protects from powerful water jets.
- IPX7  Fully splashdown. If you drop your device in water up to 3 feet your device is still going to work.

And now for the RT-20:
- IPX8  You can protect your device in water over 3 feet. This is for your stuff at the bottom of a pool, lake, or even a super deep hot tub!

Okay, I am very impressed.  This company could have gone with just an IPX7 to save money, but they went all out, and upgraded it to an IPX8 for that extra protection.

A few other, important facts.  The aluminum LED flashlight only weighs 3.4 ounces.  It feels very well built.  The lens is made of glass.  The dimensions are 5.7" X 0.9" X 1".  The dimensions make it easy to handle.  Also, I just not used this is a brand new light, just released March 30, 2016.  Maybe that is why it has all the bells and whistles.

I could go on and on, but suffice it to say the RT-20 is now on my Top 10 list.  Awesome flashlight!  I would like to buy a second one for my car.

This is a very well built router table. It gives me about 10" more space than my existing table. It also allows about 4" behind the bit when running using the fence so that you can route the channel for inlay.

I dinged a star since it did not come with the faceplate screws for my BOSCH MRP23EVS. I used the existing ones that came with the router but they are about 1/4" too short but they'll do until I can get to the hardware store. Why? It is one of the 2 routers Bosch sells that fit this. It also seems to be overly complex to assemble. It isn't a real hard thing to do but some of the screws have nuts pre-installed and they were put on the wrong screw. Not a big deal once you realize that not all of them are correctly matched. I also don't know why the router plate is adjustable up and down on the table. Couldn't they just make it the right size and call it a day?

I used this with a plunge router and you will be surprised how much force you need to exert to plunge it. It is enough to lift the entire table. So it is better to plunge it almost all the way before installing the plate and then use your micro adjustment to raise and lower it. Mine gives about an inch of lift.

The dust collection port is about useless. It should have been under the router or at least have an optional vacuum port underneath. 95% of the wood chips come out the bottom of the table.

Aftermarket DEWALT XRP DC9071 replacement battery. Ni-MH, 12-Volt, 3000mAh battery appears new and charges normally in DEWALT charger. Do not notice any difference between factory XRP, Ni-CD, 2400mAh and this Ni-MH, 3000mAh product in use.

DEWALT website states only voltage not material or mAh rating makes a difference in power.  However higher mAh battery should work somewhat longer between recharges.

DEWALT recommends recharging XRP Ni-CD battery immediately when power drop is observed.  Do not completely discharge the battery before recharging as this will reduce battery life.

Ni-MH has less memory effect than NI-CD so this battery unit may be charged or topped off before needing recharging.  Otherwise recharge per DEWALT XRP recommendations.

Man, I can't say enough good things about this lantern! First of all, tho, make sure you get the shorter one (check with a ruler) rather than the longer one. This shorter one is the one you want! I put mine on a shepherd's hook, one on each opposite side, in the garden near my front door, my front door is my "oasis" and relaxing area, from where I can view all of my favorite things, including these lanterns! And every time I look out my door at night or sit on my porch at dusk, the lanterns just "make" it look PERFECT! They are a "10" in my book!!  When other people write negative things about this lantern, like "cheaply made" or whatever, I think you would have to be about a foot away from it to think that, and even then, I DON'T THINK THAT! They look like they could be $100 apiece, and they are so inexpensive!  I've had mine out for nearly a year and they are still bright at night (well, it's a subdued brightness, just like you'd expect, not like 140 lumens, more like a 50.)  They have lasted beautifully through the snowy winter, also.  Love these and highly recommend.  My neighbors complement them, too.  (Update: 5/25/18, had these babies up for 1 1/2 years now, and love them more than ever!! Even under a grove of aspens (mottled sunlight), they still have enough light to light up well into the wee hours! I wish every solar product had such an excellent energy-collecting solar battery!!)
Seems well made.

This flashlight fills a niche for my light requirements while traveling.  Having a readily available power source (AA batteries) make this a very versatile tool.  I am using the Amazon Basic Ni-MH 2400mAh rechargeable AA batteries and very happy with this set-up.  Just a note, the Amazon batteries will not fit into my Maglite.  However, they will fit into the NiteCore.

The Nitecore is not as rugged as the comparable in class (AA Battery sized) Maglite.  The walls are noticeably thinner.  The gaskets and threads are not as robust.  For light duty use, it should be just fine.  My Maglights last over twenty years of near continuous use as a soldier.  Their lifetime warranty kept it in service all theses years with minor repair parts. Will have to wait a bit to see how long this Nitecore will last.

Main attraction is the slim profile, and AA battery power source, with the LED high light output.  For its weight and power source, It produce as much useable light as my non-LED SureFire 6P and almost as much as my Streamlight Super Stinger.  I like it so far.
summary: Bright LED Light Powered by AA Batteries

I have a Generac stand by generator and do not want certain items  running when it takes over  in the event of a power failure, ie window air conditioners, and basement dehumidifiers.

I have certain circuits hardwired to be shed in the event of a power failure, and use these outlets to keep other items from coming on when the generator takes over. When the power is back on, I simply reset these outlets.

It saves fuel and helps control electrical load on the generator if it were to come on due to power failure, and I'm not home to address it.
summary: Helps isolate appliances in the event of a power failure, helping to control  load put on stand-by generator.

This is a Kitchen single handle High arc spout, this gives excellent clearance, helps when you need to fill a large pot with water. The 3 function pull-out head has a weighted hose that helps to feed the hose back in after using. Flow pattern controls are on the head and are easy to use, the wide spray always returns to normal flow once pressure drops to near off. This will fit both a one hole or a three hole sinks, a cover plate is used over the two empty holes on 3 hole sinks, the Stainless Steel finish cover plate is included. The brushed stainless steel finish looks excellent, its easy to clean too. 1.8 gallon flow rate is good but I have high water pressure, I can't compare how well this works with lower water pressure but expect it should be ok.

Here is how I rate my purchases:

1 Star: The lowest score possible. Horrible. The product does not work or is not the product listed. When common sense tells me that this product shouldn't even be on the market. Zero positives.

2 Stars: The product is not exactly as described, either appearance wise or functionally. The product may still be usable but its very different to what was described. The product may have a few faults.

3 Stars: Average. Nothing special about the product. Useful but not remarkable.

4 Stars: The product is as described and functions well. There may be a few minor issues, but all in all, the product is solid.

5 Stars: The product is amazing! I love it! This is the highest of the highs. I would recommend it to my friends, family, and the family dog.

reviewText: I'm not a huge fan of DeWalt but I love their miter saws. They're simple, easy to adjust, accurate, compact, and durable. 10 inch miter saws are too small and sliding saws are bulky and not as accurate so this 12 inch saw is perfect for my needs. The motor is mounted in the back and drives a belt connected to the blade so it doesn't get in the way like a front mounted direct drive motor would. I've had this saw for 4 years and use it almost every day at work. It's still as accurate as the day I got it and I haven't had to replace the belt yet. My main complaint is that the dust collection bag is too small and it barely catches any sawdust in the first place. I just leave it off and clean the work area after I'm done cutting everything. You can also connect a vacuum to the dust port but it's not really practical on a job site unless you are cutting inside someone's fully finished house. Would waste too much time turning the vacuum on and off.
summary: I'm not a huge fan of DeWalt but I love their miter saws

I wanted to use the shop fox 14" band saw for a while before I wrote a review.
The saw has performed well for the six months I have used it.
Set up for the saw was fairly easy I did have a problem with the riser block, when I installed it
I had to re-tap one of the mounting bolt holes to make it fit right.
I use it for everything from re-sawing small log pieces to cutting angles for segmented bowls.
The only real problem I have had is that it seems to go through guide bearing on a regular basis.
The back support bearings went out the first week I used it and I will say that wood stock international
sent me new bearings right away. The only problem was the hassle of calling them several times.
I now just keep a supply of the bearings on hand they are very inexpensive. I purchase them from
VXB.com bearings. The part numbers are  (6000-ZZ Premium metal shields 6000 2Z ball bearing 6000-2Z bearings ABEC3)
for the backup support bearings and (608-2RS two side rubber seals bearing 608-rs ball bearings 608 rs)for the
guide bearings. Backup bearings are 10 for $9.09 and the guide bearings are 10 for $6.60.
In all fairness I say replace on regular basis but its about every 2 months.
The dust collection isn't great but adequate, but than none of the tools in my shop are perfect.
All in all I would recommend the saw to a friend.
This is three months later I have found some thing about the saw I would like to share.
I reviewed an Alex Snodgrass band saw  clip on utube, in it he said to check that the rubber tire was glued down
to the wheel. It wasn't! I had some trouble throwing blades off the saw and the no glue was the problem.
It was not glued from the factory so just FYI. I would recommend viewing it. I set the saw up to his specs and it
made a world of difference on how the saw ran. I also found that the thrust bearings on the saw are not the best
they used a mounting where the blade hit the side of the bearing, the best I think hit the bearing from the front.
Carter makes a replacement kit for this but its $179 I think, a little expensive. I cut a lot of green wood and I found that they make a two teeth per inch hook blade that really works. I couldn't find them on amazon. I order mine from Suffolk saw in Princeton Idaho. I hope these help, a slight demerit on shop fox with a few of these upgrades they could have made a better saw.
These were exactly what I wanted. No surprises when I got them as the reviewers had said the screws were too small so I was prepared. I would definitely purchase more of these.

reviewText: I paid too much for this super wide painters tape, but it was worth EVERY penny!  You can get the side of a rollerhead on it and its plenty wide enough to keep the paint off of surfaces it shouldn't be on (like my fireplace and wood cabinetry).  The adhesive on this tape is not messy like masking tape, and it sticks well while still being easily removable.  Unlike masking tape, I can keep this painters tape on for days through a couple coats of paint and still be able to easily remove it without taking the paint off with it.  This 60-yard roll was all I needed for my whole-house remodel (although I did use a couple thinner width rolls around door woodwork).  Great stuff!

This is the third flashlight like this that I have purchased.  I own one and bought one for my brother in law and nephew.  So far I am very happy with this flashlight.  It comes with 4 aaa batteries which was a plus.  You have to unscrew the battery cap and take out the security plastic so the batteries can make contact.  I'm a collector of flashlights and this was a great addition.  I don't have a way to test brightness, but according to my other flashlights I would say that it pretty much is what the description says that it is.  The magnet is very strong and comes in handy for many uses whether at home or in a car.  I just love the fact that it is a regular flashlight or slide it to make it a area work light.  You have just one button.  One push and the light comes on and push it again to turn it off and the next time you push the button the area light comes on.  There is a green ring that lights up so you know the area light is on and just slide it or turn it off and on to get back to the regular flashlight.  The only thing I would change is the on/off button.  I would have liked it to be designed to hold the button down to access the area light so you wouldn't have to turn it off and on to change from flashlight to area light.  That would drive the price up probably so I'm ok with it the way it is, that was just a thought.  Overall I'm really pleased with this flashlight and so far it is working great.  It is half the price of the competition and that is why I bought this brand.  For the money it is well worth buying as long as it stays working good.  I did buy this flashlight and was asked if I would review it for a discount and I happily agreed.
Only problem is medium is more like small to medium. You should order large if you think you have medium size hands. but they fit me good enough. I should have ordered large.

This is the first flashlight I grab when I'm doing most every day things: walking the dogs, need light under the counter, etc. It's bright enough to light up a room, but not too bright where if you accidentally shine it in someone's eyes, its going to blind them. Pros: Good level of light output Comfortable to hold & small enough to put in your jacket pocket (although I wouldn't want to carry it around all day - but it has a caribener clip on the end, so if you're carrying it a lot, you easily can) Runs on AA batteries, not expensive digital camera batteries (i.e. the CRV123 type batteries) Excellent (and I can't stress this enough, EXCELLENT) battery life. I bought it about 4 months ago, use it every day for about 25 minutes and the batteries are still going strong. Yellow case so its easy to find. Stands up easily Cons: Not bright enought, at least for me, to go deep in the woods with Could have had one flat side to avoid rolling (admittedly, these are both nitpicky cons, and I haven't had any issues with it rolling since I stand it up) If you're looking for something to go deep in the woods or you need A LOT of light, try this Dorcy Dorcy 41-4750 180 Lumen High Flux LED Cyber Light Flashlight with Batteries. If you're looking for more of an every day, go out and walk the dogs, looking for something around the house, this is absolutely perfect.

This bad boy blows away any other heat resistant glove we have worn.

Although we haven't employed it for BBQ use, we have employed it for dozens of fires and its still rockin' like Elvis back in 'da day.

Very well thought out, stylish, and versatile.  Can be used on either hand comfortably and it does what its supposed to do.

Originally we were going to purchase a higher-priced product that does the same thing, but we opted to try this instead and if this didn't work then bite the bullet on the other one.  Thankfully that hasn't been needed.

Only complaint is that these don't come as a pair, but that is okay.  The price is more then fair when you consider what one unit of these will do.

Over the countless fires we haven't had any issues, and although you can feel some heat [naturally], as long as you're not getting into a blast furnace you should be okay.

We will probably purchase 3 more of these in order to have 2 pairs for the future.  Still, one of these still rocks the house and offers added safety when dealing with firecraft.

Unfortunately this just isn't a good power supply for LED lights.  For components or electronics it's probably adequate.  However, for LED's it is unable to maintain a solid clean power supply.  Once the power supply is under even a low load, it begins to fluctuate voltage wildly at times.  I am running approximately 4.5 meters of led strips, wired in parallel every 6 foot to limit voltage drop.  The LED's will emit a subtle flicker randomly, which is indicative of a stressed PSU.  On an oscilloscope the power supply seems to struggle with maintaining constant clean power above 1 amp.  I do not at all believe this PSU could handle 6 amps constant, possibly bursting to 6amp, but solid load, no.
summary: Adequate for components, not for LED's.

Tragically, a local father and his young son recently died as a result of CO poisoning and that was my motivation for this purchase. Even though I have a CO detector on every level of my home, including the basement, they are all hard wired, meaning they won't work if the power goes out. I also don't know how old they are since I'm not the original home owner and I believe CO detectors have a certain life span before they become less effective.
I have owned Kidde (pronounced Kidda not Kiddie) products in the past and thought they were okay products for the money so I went with this one.
The minimum level to activate it is 70ppm whereas I've seen other detectors at 60ppm. I don't think the extra 10ppm matters. I didn't want the plug in type since it constantly uses electricity. I thought about getting the sealed battery type with the 10 year Lithium battery, but I won't be in my house for 10 years and I don't want to get one that's been sitting in a warehouse for 2 or 3 of those 10 years as some reviews have reported. I'm okay with spending a few bucks every year to replace the batteries.
I also didn't want one with a display or backlight. For one, a display/backlight will use up more battery power and thus require more frequent battery replacement. For another, I don't need to see what the ppm reading is. If the alarm triggers, that's enough for me to know there's a problem. I don't need to see a digital readout of how close I came to dying.
This unit is compact so it makes placement easier and it doesn't make itself as easily spotted as larger devices.
I did NOT experience any issue with the unit beeping when it should not be beeping after inserting the batteries.
It also has a 5 year warranty.
I was so satisfied I ordered a second unit today for the second floor. It's inexpensive insurance. Regardless of what brand you go with, every home should have at least one.
summary: Good value, good size, just what was needed

[Update 9/22/2014]  I finally got tired of the noise from this fan and contacted Quiet Cool.  They offered me a replacement motor that was two speed for $150.  I accepted and they shipped it to me. QuietCool has a video on their web site on how to replace a fan motor.

So I took the fan unit out of the attic, leaving the duct work.  When I disassembled the motor housing, I discovered that the motor I had was exactly the same as the motor they shipped me - but the red wire (the half speed connection) and the ground wire had been cut off.  I was able to solder a wire to each - the red and ground wires. I tested the motor and it worked fine at half speed.  Luckily, the way I had wired the original unit gave me enough wires to run it as a two speed unit.  I bought a single pole, double throw, center off Decor switch to control the unit.  Works fine now and is MUCH quieter on half speed than at full speed.  I'm able to run the fan at night now.

I contacted Quiet Cool and they approved my returning the motor to them.  To their credit, they refunded the entire amount, including the shipping cost.  All I had to pay was the shipping to return the motor to them.  Kudos to Quiet Cool.

The thing I'm wondering is why did they cut the red and green wires on the motor of the unit they sent me?  The two speed unit is the same price as the one speed unit so why cripple the unit like that?

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

[Original review - 9/19/2012]  Where I live, we often have cool evenings and nights, even if the day is warm (or hot).  I wanted to have a fan that could bring in the cool evening air to save me some money on air conditioning.

There's good and bad about this unit.  The good:
1. The grill that shows in the ceiling is not very obvious.  The flappers are up above the grill so they don't show and the vent is flush with the ceiling.
2. Installation is not too difficult and the instructions are very clear.  The fan will not fit through the vent opening so it has to be brought up through the attic access panel.  I took the duct work off of the fan so that I could transport the duct separate from the fan. If you do that, mark the location so you can put the screws back into the same holes.

The bad:
1.  It's not as quiet as I was led to believe.  I called Quiet Cool and discussed this with them before buying the unit.  They said it was about the same noise level as an air conditioner and that it could be installed in the bedroom and run during the night without problems.  That certainly is not true for me.  The unit has a significant "air movement" sound that is objectionable for use during the sleep hours, and I have the fan installed in the hallway outside my bedroom.
2.  At 3200 cfm, the fan does not bring the cool air in very quickly.  I think a larger unit, or multiple units of this size, would be needed to really cool the house off in a reasonable period of time.

Part of the noise problem may be that the intake area is somewhat small, being designed to fit between two ceiling joists.  A larger vent area, a fan with longer blades that turned slower, and yet gave the same air movement volume, would probably help the noise.

A good feature that Quiet Cool could add to this fan would be a two speed fan motor so that the fan could be slowed down for night time use - assuming that the slower speed would reduce the noise significantly.
summary: Some good, some bad about this fan

reviewText: Needs web integration

The Energizer Trail Finder Pro 7 LED Headlamp is a versatile light source that provides three different levels of illumination, a red light mode for night vision, and a strobe mode for emergencies.  There are two red, and five white LEDs, arranged to provide a nice wide field of coverage.  Maximum output is 100 lumens, with all five white LEDs on.

Powered by three AAA batteries (which are included), the unit is controlled by the power button located on the top of the lamp.  Pressing once puts the headlamp into the red light mode.  Continuing to press the button, causes the light to cycle through the various modes, finishing with the strobe mode.

The performance of the headlight is very good, as it provides a nice level of illumination, over a fairly wide field of view, however there are other aspects that majorly detract from the products usability.  The headband lacks a piece that goes over the top of the head, which makes the light prone to sliding around, depending on how much you move your head, and the amount of hair you have.

The real annoyance is the way the hinge operates.  A plate rests against the forehead, while the light clicks through to one of four positions.  The problem is that in the first two positions, if you look up, or tilt your head upwards, gravity causes the headlamp to swing back so that it rests against the forehead.  If you are looking around, and moving your head up and down, having to adjust and reposition the light, can quickly become ridiculous and frustrating.  Having the light bang against your head, gets pretty annoying as well.  When you pivot the light into the last two positions, it does lock into place, but you also begin to get some glare in your eyes.  So there are some BIG practical issues with this product.

While the luminaire is a very good 4 star performer, the poor design drops my rating to just 2 stars.  When I use a headlamp, I frequently need to adjust the angle of the light, and having a headlamp that automatically repositions itself is quite maddening.  I own a number of headlamps, and this Energizer is the only one that does something this crazy.
summary: versatile light source, with a really annoying quirk

reviewText: Much better than a hand reamer. Buy this if you run lots of emt.

My house was built in 1931. It has unpainted stucco on it. This stuff matches exactly. I used it to fill a hole that appeared around the frame of a door after my house was power washed. I just used my hands to slap it on and then I smoothed it a bit with a pain multi-tool. Since it was a deep hole, I ended up doing this twice. It took just a few moments each time. You cannot tell the difference between the original stucco and this. This was about two weeks ago and it has held perfectly. I couldn't be more pleased.

I will note, that in buying a second container, I found it to be of a different consistency than the first. It was a bit dried out, I think. I was still able to use it, but based on what other say, there is, perhaps, a consistency problem or maybe a container problem. If you find that you receive a container with a broken or open lid, you would be best off returning it and trying again. Dried out, this stuff is really not usable. A bit dried out, it can be hard to work with.

Update - Fall 2015

I had a serious crack in two places on my house. One I had repaired professionally. It is already cracking again. The other I had a handyman fix by putting on some silicon, letting that cure, and putting this over the silicon. This latter choice was the one to make. For substantially less money, I have a well-repaired area on my house. Once it warms up again, I am going to have the handyman use this patch over the area that the so-called professionals repaired.

The pictures I included show the before and after of a pretty serious crack that was on the sidewall on my driveway.

Update January, 2016

Some months have passed since I first used this product to repair a hole around my doorway. Now even I don't remember where the hole was and I cannot find it. I pointed out the general area to guests, they couldn't find it either. If you have painted stucco, this won't match exactly, but it should do the job of covering up the area. You will just need to paint over it later. I cannot speak to how this holds paint. If you have unpainted stucco, you may find that this matches precisely, as it does on my house.  This product has saved me a great deal of money.
summary: Very Pleased - Matches my House Exactly

reviewText: excellent

This unit replaced a Lux 1500 7-day programmable unit.  I need a Tstat that I could use and be able to monitor / edit via the web.  This unit worked out very well.  A few install notes that need to be considered.  My old stat did not have a C wire run, so I ran new thermostat wire (easy enough).  The old stat had battery backup on it, but this one does not.  The old unit had a dedicated Light button to illuminate the display.  This unit has no such light, however the unit will light up when any button is pushed.  As a result, we have had numerous instances where we hit the Hold button in order to light up the stat, only to find hours later that the unit was still held

Accessing the stat via web is a real nice feature.  I do this with both my laptop and my android phone.  Sadly, there is no Kindle app yet.  When accessed online, you can make any temperature and schedule changes as needed.  You can also change fan settings.  You can not make performance changes to the system though, as these must be done at the unit.  One pet peave about the online access though, it displays the outdoor temperature and humidity, yet the temps do not always align with what is found via the standard weather sources, sometimes the temp has been up to 15 deg f off.  Today it is about -3 at home, yet online the stat says it is -12.

I have found that with this unit installed, my furnace has been running very smoothly and not nearly as hard as with the old unit.  My furnace is a high efficiency gas modulating model.
summary: I love it, but it still has a few spots to improve on....

These lights can be used in cabinets, closets, bathrooms, hallways - anywhere (indoors) you need an extra light source.

What I Like about this Solar Motion Light
1. Combined with batteries, this little light can shine appx. 2500 times before replacement batteries are needed. That's a lot of use! (Though if you have pets running through your house, the life of the batteries will fade quickly. Rechargeable batteries would be the way to go.)
2. It detects movement up to 15 feet away.
3. The light can be installed anywhere.
4. It comes with a 1-year money back guarantee.

What Could Be Improved

But it would make a great gift for an elderly person who wakes up during the night and needs to go to the restroom. It could prevent them from falling in the dark. There are dozens of uses for this little light, and if you like it, you may want more than one for your home.

Smooth operator. I love this Makita saw. It has served me well. I use it for many different things from cutting 2x material to cutting trim and hardwoods. The stock blade is ok and will last a little while. I have freud blades in mine and love the silky smooth operation and consistent power.

The blade guard rarely gets in the way and is easy to to raise. The bevel and depth adjustments are easy to reach and operate and hold well. The sole plate is sturdy and maintains its position well. The LED light is a nice touch. It only comes on while the trigger is depressed unlike Makita's cordless drills which have a slow ramping off feature that slowly dims the LED after the trigger is released which makes for a nice flashlight. I guess you shouldn't be expecting to use your cordless saw as a light source anyway.

The battery last a long while on a full charge. You can saw thru a good amount of wood with a thin kerf blade. I've cut over 50 2x6's on a single charge.

I've had mine for over a year now and it's been a dream to use. I wouldn't trade it for anything else.
summary: Great Little Trim Saw. Wouldn't Trade It For The World!

This set is well made solid tool steel. It will not loose its shape any soon. Here are my comments:
Comes with a nice case, although re-inserting all the rings back is a hassle. The ratcheting handle works efficiently and does not slip. For most US rebuilds, like an SBC 350 you'll need only one ring that goes to 4 1/8" inches. Thus far, that too grabbed the piston fine.
However, insertion into the cylinder requires a little finesse; first do not tightly squeeze the ring. Leave it as tight as it goes with the ratchet. Second, when tapping the piston down also tap along the sides of the ring. You do this because, depending of how you are holding the ratchet, it may lift the ring just a little and the oil-scraper ring will pop out. If you keep that in mind you'll be OK. WORK SLOWLY AND REMEMBER TO WORK SLOWLY!

Good overall for the price. It's not the highest quality, fairly thin plastic, but it does what it is supposed to do, and that is protect your face.  It does attract a lot of dust being plastic, but wiping it down occasionally with an anti-static dryer sheet helps out considerably.

reviewText:
I occasionally do odd carpentry jobs for people and some remodeling in my own house. I bought this kit in February, 2009. I don't use it day-after-day for weeks on end, but I have put all the tools (even the flashlight is powerfully bright) through their paces. All tools perform well enough for me but I use the cordless drill and impact driver the most by far. These are the first drivers I've owned that have headlights in the form of an LED. I love this feature so much I'll never do without again. Once you have them, you realize how often you're working in a poorly illuminated area.

My one complaint about the cordless drill is that the function selector - the sliding switch on top that allows the user to select either drill, screw or hammer-drill mode - will sometimes get stuck. Usually I have to loosen/tighten the chuck and pull the trigger quickly to get it to move to another position.

No complaints about the impact driver. It's solid and has plenty of power.

The circular saw is a little wimpy as others have mentioned. But with a sharp blade and charged battery, it handles 2x stock pretty easily. And most of the time, I'm only cutting a few pieces at a time and it's much easier to reach for this small, lightweight saw than my 10-lb plug-in.

Recip saw has worked fine for me. I use this guy the least, and then only for a few cuts so I can't say how well it performs day in and day out.

The angle grinder is just ok. The blade shield does not have a quick-release so each time you want to reposition the it you have to grab your screw driver, loosen, reposition and tighten. I try to tighten it just enough to keep it in position, but loose enough to move it by hand, but that doesn't hold for very long of course. It'll start to slip which results in much cursing. I have a Makita plug-in angle grinder with a quick-release shield. Almost every time I use my cordless grinder, I've needed to shift the shield position, often more than once. And each time, I curse Makita for this penny-wise, pound-foolish choice.

Now, to what I consider the important part of the review: the Power Source. If your batteries are unreliable or insufficient, there really is little point in owning battery-powered tools. Let my experience (or lack of) be a lesson to you if you're considering buying any rechargeable battery-operated device.

Be absolutely sure about the protocols of use and charging for your particular brand/model/type of battery before you embark on your making and destroying. If there's nothing else from this review you take away (it's already getting long-winded), you should know that with these Makita Lithium-ions, you should charge them up as soon as you notice the power in your tool decreasing. I repeat. AS SOON AS you notice the power in your tool decreasing. AND, although you can leave the battery in the charger after it has fully-charged (it will go into trickle-charge mode), you should not put a fully charged battery back into a charger. The manuals of both the Makita Fast Charger and individual tools that come with this kit offer conflicting and confusing instructions about battery-charging. And frankly, I wouldn't be surprised if it were intentional. One replacement battery for the LXT tools costs about $70.

I bought the LXT601 in February, 2009. After about a year and a half (warranty is only one year) both the batteries start to intermittently fail to charge. When this happens, the Fast Charger blink pattern indicates that the batteries are "damaged" and cannot be charged. I'm usually a good manual-reader but in this case, I didn't read them carefully enough*. I can't remember whether the batteries in this kit themselves had a manual but I have nothing in my operating manual files (i.e. I save all my operating manuals in a cabinet). Upon rereading the manuals, the Fast Charger does not warn against overly discharging the Li-ion batteries.

*However, the individual tool manuals all note the following: "Charge the battery cartridge before completely discharged." BUT IN THE VERY NEXT SENTENCE SAY, "Always stop tool operation and charge the battery cartridge when you notice less tool power." Well, which one is it? If you don't read those two sentences and immediately get authoritative confirmation of which protocol is correct, you may end up like me and unconsciously tell yourself that it really doesn't matter what you do as long as you don't drain it all the way before recharging, because hey, these are contractor-grade tools right? If you notice your drill's torque getting weaker but you only need to drill another 10 screws should you have to worry that you might be significantly shortening the life of your battery if you proceed to drain it further?

btw, without a lot of effort, you'll find a fair number of frustrated Makita LXT series tool owners complaining of pre-mature battery failure. Some even mention getting free replacements from Authorized Service facilities for batteries that were past their warranty date.

So when I called Makita sometime late 2010 in an effort to get my out-of-warranty batteries replaced, the arrogant service rep. insisted my pre-mature battery failure was due to user error and not faulty batteries because 1) the number of manufacturing defects was very, very small and 2) I'd obviously been draining them all the way down because that's why these batteries fail prematurely. It sounded like she had dealt with her fair share of battery calls. I admitted that I'd sometimes run them even after noticing power decreasing. Not to dead, but to no-longer-useful. That sunk any chances of replacement I had if I'd had any to begin with. Unfortunately I didn't point out the conflicting manual directives because I hadn't re-read them like I did just recently. I should have, I know.

In any case, after the fruitless call, I took my croaking batteries to a local Authorized Makita facility. They were now failing to charge about 50-75% of the time. The tech hooked up the batteries to his special battery machine and told me each battery reported about 60 charge cycles, a woefully low number of cycles for batteries that were near-useless. He was able to verify that one battery, which initially reported "charging", reported as "damaged" in short order. The other battery seemed to take a charge successfully. He admitted be couldn't explain why the failure was intermittent but he was willing to sell me new batteries because mine were no longer covered by the warranty. Like the service rep on the phone, he told me that I should remember to charge the batteries when I notice the power decreasing. Unwilling to fork over another $140 to Makita, I took my semi-damaged batteries and left in disgust.

It's now November 2012 and I am (not quite) happy to report that I still have those batteries which, after a few charge/discharge cycles where I put them into the charger as soon I noticed power decreasing, now rarely report a "damaged"/can't-charge condition.

btw, there is another confusing set of battery instructions you should be aware of:  In the tool manuals, the instructions say to "Never recharge a fully charged battery cartridge." The Fast Charger manual says under the Trickle Charge (Maintenance Charge) section: "If you leave the battery cartridge in the charger to prevent spontaneous discharging after a full charge, the charger will switch into its 'trickle charger (maintenance charge)' mode and keep the battery cartridge fresh and fully charged."

In other words, it's ok to leave the battery in the charger, but not ok to take it out after it's successfully charged and put it back in; or leave it in there if the power to the charger is accidentally cut off then turned on again. These instructions can only lead to the conclusion that the charger doesn't have the circuitry to detect how much charge is on a newly attached battery and respond appropriately.

So beware: If you're not careful about your battery usage, they turn into the ink jet cartridges of your power tool world.

*********************

Update 9/8/14: I'm happy to report that the two batteries that came with this kit are still useful and have been charging successfully almost every time I put them in the charger. I'd say 9 out of the last 10 times. Remember to swap out the battery as soon as you start noticing power decreasing in your tool.
summary: Good for homeowner, but batteries need pampering

reviewText:
I have to say that  had no idea that there were plugs like this until I had the chance to try this plug out myself. I liked the idea of being able to have some of my lights on plugs like these because I could see many great uses for this, especially when I was away from the house.

When I received this and took it out of the box, I found it to be lightweight and seemingly simplistic in exterior. When I looked through the instructions it also seemed that it would be simple to setup too. My initial impression was not incorrect. You have to connect to this with an app on your phone. I have an Android phone, and found that the download of the app and its' use was easy to install and use. Once I connected the app, I found that it immediately connected to the lamp that I had it connected with. I did find there was a short delay (only about 20 seconds) from when I connect the app to when it turns the lamp on itself. I found that it worked both at home and away from home. I tried using the application when I was about 20 miles away and even a bit closer and when my family got home they told me that the lamp was on.

So thus far this does a great job and definitely meets a need that we have. Seeing that our whole family is busy, we came to find that there were some nights when it was not until it was dark that we got home. That being said we were able to turn on the light when needed to light up the home at a certain point in time. We also went away on vacation, and this allowed us to turn on and off a light when we wanted making the home look lived in while we were away.

All-in-all, thus far I am enjoying this and am even thinking of moving this to another lamp in another room, but time will tell if that is what we decide or not.

*I received this for review - all opinions are my own*
summary: Works well from near or far!

I tried using this product, and its spray can version, on some unfinished tin tile panels.  This paint is similar to working with epoxy glue, but using the spray can is better than the quart cans.  It is very thick in order to produce the hammered effect, which by the way it does so-so.  It certainly doesn't look like the label suggests.  More importantly, there is no brand of rollers known to man, including Purdy, that doesn't get lots of fibers stripped and embedded in the paint.  The paint gives you mere seconds to work with it, and if you go over the same area twice within a few seconds like a normal painter does, it produces long strings that become embedded in the paint.  It was just a hideous mess.  It ruined my project, cost me immense time and expense to strip and repaint, and I complained so bitterly to Rustoleum that I told them to yank it off the shelves.  I strongly suggest to others that they use another brand if they want this effect.
summary: The Other Reviewers Have To Be Kidding !

reviewText: Great quality

I had been looking for a motion sensor light bulb for my back porch for a while. The porch has a wall mounted light fixture with an E27 socket and a fixed glass enclosure, so any motion sensor apparatus that I got would have to fit inside the fixture. I also wanted an LED bulb. This light bulb with a built-in infrared sensor works perfectly. All I had to do was screw it into the socket and it automatically turned on when it sensed motion after sundown (the manufacturer lists the detection range as 10-14 feet). It shuts itself off when motion is no longer detected. It doesn't turn on during daylight, which saves on energy. As for brightness, the manufacturer states the bulb has 620lm, and an incandescence equivalent of 45 watts, which is bright enough to light up my porch, but not so bright as to be annoying. The wattage is only 7 watts, so it doesn't use much energy. For the price, I think this is a great motion-sensor lightbulb. I received this product at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.
summary: 10-14 feet motion-sensing energy-saving LED light bulb

reviewText: Nevermind the crappy picture the item is great.  I have used it multiple times and will continue to use it for a long time.  These are made to last and even come with a great case.  Very easy to use and self explained.

I was in the market for a small general purpose flashlight and the positive reviews led me to the this one. My goals were:

1) LED-based for high brightness and long battery longevity
2) Use of standard AA batteries
3) Durability
4) Ease of use

This one fits all those criteria and so far I'm pretty happy with it. It's extremely bright. I see people squabbling over lumens and comparing one light to another in some of the other reviews. Whatever this one measures out at, it's plenty bright enough for any conceivable purpose. Where I think it differs from some of the other lights is that it has a wider angle. Thus it's not quite as good for eliminating a fixed "spot" at a distance as some other lights. It's more than adequate in service as a general purpose light, and it excels at giving a broad beam at close range (Terralux specifically recommended this one for technicians needing to illuminate areas behind panels, etc).

Use of standard AA batteries is definitely a plus for me. I find them much more convenient than AAA or some weird lithium specialty battery. I've tried it with both the included duracell alkalines and some Apple rechargeable (like rebranded eneloop NiMH). It performs well on either.

As far as ease of use, it has a simple click-on/click-off tail switch. You give it a quick tap to switch between intensities. No weird turns or tilts or multi-clicks. For a general purpose light you want it to be simple.

So far it seems quite durable. The button in conveniently recessed in the tail. The case it all metal. There's an O-right seal for the battery chamber.

It's good enough that I'm probably going to stock up on more of them.
summary: Bright, Convenient, Durable, Easy to Use

At first this looks like any knife that has a tension ball detente mechanism. These types of knives are good but I always worry about putting too much force on the blade for fear that the detente lock will fail. This knife solves this by offering a second lock that locks the detente I place. With the look engaged its virtually impossible for the blade to close. I like this design. Also the blade is strong enough to be a good too but not so long that it qualifies as a weapon under many jurisdictions. First off, let me say the Energizer LED Folding 360 Area Lantern was a welcome replacement for the oil lanterns and candles we once used during power outages.

We tested this model on the late afternoon of Sunday, July 21, when Pacific Power had an equipment problem at a substation in our city, causing more than 4,500 homes to lose power for up to eight hours. Our home was one of the last to have power restored, so we had plenty of time to test the Energizer LED Folding 360 Area Lantern.

Initially, I loaded four AA batteries into the lantern but we switched to eight (as per the instructions) for maximum run time during the power outage. The smart dimming technology is fantastic. We could `tap' down the light intensity, allowing us to use the lantern at the dinner table without blinding anyone. With a couple more taps, my family could ramp up the light intensity for use down the hallway.

The caveat here is Energizer's decision to use plastic screws to hold the battery compartment. We stripped the screws on our first try, so now they fall out of place if the lantern is rotated too much to its front side. This isn't a problem so long as the textured, plastic lid is closed. The lantern has a durable, easy-grip handle and a retractable kick-stand that allows the product to sit upright on a table.

Eight AA batteries gave us all the light we needed during our eight-hour power outage. I haven't tested in for longer periods. If Energizer would come up with a better locking mechanism for the battery compartment, I would raise my rating by two stars. For now, this lantern is two screws shy of a five-star rating.

Rating: Three stars.

My objective is to test and review products fairly, providing you with helpful information that improves your shopping experience. ADDENDUM (Key information to share from the comments):

Snaby says:
They are not screws they are latches, if you look really carefully next to them there is an etched symbol showing to spin them a quarter turn to unlock. Reading though the reviews it seems Energizer should have made this etching a little more obvious as apparently a lot of people have made the same mistake and overturned the latches. Hope this helps anybody else that purchases this product because it really is a very nice lantern all things considered.

Jared Castle says:
Thank you. You are correct. The latches aren't intuitive and we turned them too far. Except for the latch, I have no complaints.

flyer says:
You might edit your review to incorporate this new insight -- if I had not read the comment I would have avoided this light based on your otherwise excellent review.
summary: Two screws shy of a five-star rating

This is a MONSTER of a faucet. It's super tall, and super heavy.  But it's absolutely gorgeous, solid quality, and well thought out.  I have to admit, it suddenly made my low/mid-range stainless steel sink look cheap.

First off, the finish.  I am in love with it. It's not your shiny "cheap" looking stainless... it's a nice, brushed stainless steel that matches most appliance stainless steel finishes.  It's really stunning!!

It's also easy to use and has a lot of neat features: the handle blends in so much easier to the neck. It's a little weird that to get hot water you have to move the lever forward; but I'll get used to it.  The pull down feature is a little stiff, but it works really well once you get the hang of it. It has a "stop flow" button on the back side of the head; so you can pause your water flow without messing with the lever. It has a spray and a flow button too... and I have to say, the flow on this thing is MEAN.  Almost a bit too much, it's a powerhouse, that's for sure!

Actual structure is sooo solid.  Really nice, metal pieces, not a whole lot of plastic and strong in all the right places. I see this faucet lasting for forever.

My only complaint is that my sink is apparently too weak to handle it in the middle hole. It's okay; but the faucet is a little wobbly because my stainless sink is apparently not super strong in the middle hole area; at least for a faucet of this height and weight. I had to move it to the side; and that's okay because this faucet has REALLY good reach; it has a nice, long arch to it.  I never realized my sink was not of the highest quality. LOL  That's HOW GOOD this faucet is!!

It's really gorgeous installed... very classic but with a bit of a modern look with the handle.  But not too modern to annoy this totally traditional housewife. :)  It's really like a semi truck on a sink... just huge and amazing!
summary: HUGE, solid and gorgeous brushed stainless steel faucet... is a workhorse!

There are many things to like about this knife. Lightweight, wicked sharp out of the box, fairly easy to open and close. However, for this left-hander I was disappointed to discover that the thumb stud is on one side only. Email to Leatherman resulted in a notice that any attempt to modify the knife would void the warranty. That said, it turns out that if one is VERY careful (remember the wicked sharp), with an appropriately sized drive pin, a hammer, and (in my case) a small socket as platform, it is possible to remove the thumb stud and relocate it to the other side of the blade, with a pair of pliers for pressure it snaps back into place. I can't emphasize enough, doing this is DANGEROUS.

That said, I now have a knife I can open with my left hand. I've found I prefer the Gerber Evo Jr which comes out of the box with a dual-sided thumb stud and a nice flipper tab that once fully opened becomes a finger guard. Both knives, since they have open backs, tend to collect coins and whatnot from your pocket. The Evo Jr is a smaller knife, and your preference is likely to depend in part on the size of your hands; mine are on the smaller side.

I've done more than 10 baseboard installs in the last year and I finally got to use this tool! Taking off the old base was actually
fun.  Really useful. It's wide base makes pulling large sections with much less damage easier. The integral "spring" mechanism
 pushes the baseboard out as you tamp down on the tool with a hammer. Also, the wide base speeds up the  job by leveraging
 longer sections at a time.

One caveat I will offer- if your old base is caulked make sure you use a utility knife to cut the joint before you start
pulling the base because this tool with it's weight and width is pretty forceful in pulling the base from the wall and you
will tear the paper on the wall board if you don't thoroughly cut the caulk line first.

Easily a 5 star tool and recommendation.

These work great. I had 6 bulbs in my outside carriage lamps, and over the 3 years since I've been here, I had to replace each one at least once. They were also 60 watts, so I was burning 360 watts a night, I mean an hour. I couldn't find any LED bulbs that were the right size without spending a mint on each one, until I saw these. Before I bought them, I wanted to make sure the bulbs would be the right size, which they seemed to be, and when I received them, I found out they were. The filament is a set of two long electrodes (for want of the right term) that burn nice and bright. Now my electricity bill should go down a lot. At 1.8 watts each, that's only 10.8 watts total, hardly anything at all. I don't feel bad about leaving them on all night now.
Just updated with a couple of photos to show how bright these are. Although not 'overly' bright, they are bright enough, and I like the way they look. I haven't had any burn out, whereas with the other bulbs, I would have had to replace 2 or 3 by now since I put these in. I just ordered 2 others in the A15 size for under he porch, as one of those bulbs went out (the ones under the globe at the moment are normal 60w A15's, not LED's)

update 7-13-16. Still burning bright, none have burned out, and since I have now all LED's in the house, my electric went down $30 plus a month, it's now less than $100 a month, for our 2 story 3000sq/ft. house. (we also have gas).
summary: my electricity bill should go down a lot now

I needed a very small hex wrench, .035", because I'd lost my original.  The original was lost because it's [censored] tiny!

The carrier is bright tool plastic yellow, and it's got that nifty little hole in it.  The hole is theoretically intended for screwing the thing to the wall or something.  I dunno why you'd do that, but I used it to attach a dummy cord to it.  The other end of the cord is attached to my bag.  Where my bag goes, these little keys go.

Thus far I've used the .035" and the 1/16" keys.  Both held up to breaking "red" thread locker, though carefully in the case of the .035" size.  I'm impressed.

reviewText: Very helpful as a third and fourth hand when soldering. Though I ditched the magnifying glass first thing. It just gets in the way.

I got this kit to run air lines around my garage and at some point into the basement. If I didn't care about the basement I'm sure 1/2" would have been fine but that will be a long run so I decided to get the larger diameter. The pipe wasn't super easy to run, not like stapling up NM-B cable, but compared to running any kind of conduit I thought it was quite easy. I'm also not super OCD about getting the line super straight, but by careful unrolling and straightening you can get it reasonably good. It took me two evenings of a couple hours to run everything, mostly because parts required getting up into the attic. Heeding the advice of using ptfe tape and pipe sealant on all NPT fittings, I have absolutely no leaks, I proofed the system at 140psi and turned the supply off and even after a day the pressure held steady.

To attach my couplers at the outlets, I got 3 1/2"-1/4" brass bushings here on amazon for $2 each. It's too bad this kit doesn't come with 45-degree angles for the outlets like the 1/2" kit does. It would be better if the outlets didn't stick straight out. I did also buy a separate Maxline 1/2" fitting (M8005) since the kit comes with a 3/4" fitting for the compressor connection and my regulator has 1/2" connections.

The only reason I took a star off was that the compression fittings did not seem to go on very easily. Instructions say to tighten finger tight and thn an additional 3/4 turn. In no case was I able to go that far, and I even after putting some oil on the threads they were still galling as I tightened them. As I said, there are absolutely no leaks, so it's possible they just don't need to be tightened as much as the instructions say.
summary: Fairly quick to install, and no leaks.

My wife and I are in a house that has 2 levels and hanging lights on the roof above the garage was impossible and dangerous because of the slope of the roof so you couldn't do it from above, and I didn't have a ladder high enough to reach. BUT the you could get onto the ridge of the first level and then climb to the ridge of the second level. Only problem was you couldn't go down the roof at all because of the steepness of it. This meant we were going to go "lightless" for christmas this year.

I did check with people that hang lights professionally and the going rate was about $175.. Way too much for me to spend. So I did some searching and found these ridge mount ladder hooks. I had no idea something like this existed. After reading the reviews I wasn't sure if they would work because people mentioned how unsafe it was, etc. But I decided I could always return them if they didn't work so I pulled the trigger and ordered 2.

The box arrived and was beat to hell, but that was ok, these are made of steel and if it can't take the abuse of UPS getting it to my house there is no way I would trust it with my life. Good news, they were in perfect condition when I pulled them through the hole in the box.

I was using these on my little giant which I wasn't sure would work, but I am happy to say it did, it worked perfectly. I was able to secure both hooks (I ordered 2, they only come in single units) and did some initial tests by banging it and pulling on them to see if they would pop off, they didn't.

I was ready to hang the lights. I carried everything up to the roof then lifted my ladder up and walked along the ridge to the second level, put the ladder down and in about 7 seconds felt totally comfortable and confident. There was no wobble, no shaking. These things held onto the roof well with no damage to it and kept the ladder exactly where I wanted it. I was able to then climb down the ladder which was hooked onto the ridge and hang lights along the slope of the roof. I then got to the bottom where the gutter was and sat on the bottom run and felt secure while attaching lights along the gutter. I had to climb up to the ridge, move the ladder over a few feet and then climb back down and start all over as I was doing part of the roof, but the entire time I felt 100% safe.

The cost to have someone hang lights on my rood was $175. These cost me $21 each for a total of $42. It took me less then an hour to do my lights and I saved $133 PLUS these things will last for years. This is one of the best tool purchases I have ever made, I love these hooks. If you need something like this get these, but note they only come in single units so you need to order 2. Some people say you can use just one, I wouldn't trust it. With 2 the ladder is held at 2 points which prevents it from swinging side to side. With one who knows what could happen. I submitted 2 pictures of my ladder on my roof as well.

If you found my review helpful please marm it as so!

I've had a Toto toilet in the main bathroom for 8 years and they are superior to any toilet on the market. I am now creating a second bathroom in the basement. I was going to use a contractor but he wanted to use an American Standard toilet and told me that they COPIED Toto's design and were now "as good". At that point I decided that he was blowing smoke and that I'd do the bathroom myself at a slower pace. Called in a plumber to do what plumbers do and when he saw the Toto toilet said "Oh, you bought the best toilet on the market". I told him about the contractor who said American Standard was "as good" as Toto and he laughed and said no they aren't. The plumber is right. The Toto Drake is a great toilet. This one is the higher rise toilet which makes a huge difference when you are getting older and don't have to squat down so far. The low flow flush works incredibly well and large amounts of wastes do not clog it. They cost a bit more but are without a doubt worthy of the additional price tag.

Update 6/29/18
OK I finally got off my lazy butt to build a nice big deck and shade area this week, using this little (fairly) portable compressor and my biggest Milwaukee nail gun.  It can fire the 3.5" nails at full speed and never once ran out of go.  Surprised and pleased.

It's installed in the carport on a bench with forstner holes drilled precisely to hold the rubber feet in place, so no walking or tugging it off the bench. Aired up the tires on the old saturn which seldom gets used... no problem at all.  Aired up the big 10 ply tires on my F250... took longer, but no problem at all even to high pressure.

There's a chance I'll need it someday for some of my construction tools, and if I do use it for that, I'll add a little update here.  I think it will handle all but the big Milwaukee nailer, and maybe even that for a nail or two.

This saw seemed fine when I tested it, but then I used it for an actual project.  Although the motor wasn't straining, it shut ifself off.  I reset it, and in a minute or so, it did it again.  Pretty soon, it was constantly shutting itself off.  I can't get anything done with it.

Replacing and removing the battery in this unit is pretty frustrating, and like all alarms, it has a 90% probability of running out of juice between 1:00 and 4:00 AM, so, you know - enjoy. I can understand the battery removal complexity so that the battery can not be easily removed in a hotel room or such because this unit does NOT attach to in-house wiring (I actually thought it did, because of the "also includes battery..." portion of the description). But the battery compartment needs a complete re-design. As it is, it turns the unit into a throw-away as you break the plastic parts to manage the battery in the dark at 3:00 in the morning.

The "escape light," which I thought might be an LED or some other bright light, in fact amounts to a old-school incandescent penlight flashlight bulb at best. You might be able to read your escape plan if you hold it within a few inches of the light, but it's not going to help you see where you're going any time soon. You will still step on legos and toys and the like, and since it's 3:00 in the morning, that will add extra fun to get you ready for the battery fandango. Add smoke, and I imagine the light is useless. It would be a good idea if it were brighter and wired into the other alarms to help people navigate out of dark house, but in this unit, it is a gimmick.

All told, I like that it has a photoelectric sensor, but I won't purchase another one.
summary: Battery compartment design is terrible, light is useless.

reviewText: I bought 4 of these units (two 2-packs). The settings are supposed to be "off," "on" and "motion controlled". In one of them, the motion controlled setting produces a dimmer light (about half strenght or less), and in the other, it usually does not light up at all. I opened the faulty one to see if I could spot the problem, and it is evident that the internal wiring and switch are about as cheap and flimsy as they could make it. And, while having just the on/off choices may sound fine, the switch is on the back, so that it has to be taken down to change the settings. If you plan to install this on a ceiling, be aware that the units are designed for hanging on a flat-head screw on a wall, and it will be difficutl to install on a ceiling. You would not want to stick it on with anything permanent, because the settings and battery access require removal. I installed two of these over a kitchen sink that needed a bit of extra light.  It helps brighted the area, but is certainly not enough light to work with (other than, say, to get a glass of water at night) without having the main kitchen light on. It doesn't quite seem as much light as I would have expected from 10 LEDs though.  Overall, the two units that work properly do come on with motion, do so reliably, and do cast enough light to significanlty improve the area.

AAA LED Lenser flashlight review

I've had the LED Lenser flashlight for years now (since early 2008) and still use it as it's proven to be a very reliable and bright flashlight in a small, very convenient package. This is one of my favorite flashlights because of its excellent quality of light (crisp white) and powerful focused beam. I've used it for years in all kinds of weather and never had a problem with it. During the school year I use it daily for building security checks, it's truly gotten a lot of use and surprised me by never having failed on me! The most important thing to keep in mind though is to always buy quality batteries as they make all the difference in the useful longevity of the light. Overall this is a simple and fantastic flashlight that hasn't let me down yet. I would highly recommend it!

reviewText:
I live in an apartment and needed a paint stripper that was non toxic since I have to do my handy work in the livingroom.  I needed to strip the paint from a 60" wide windowsill, and two flat panels of my radiator cover (30" x 25").  I did everything according to directions, covered the applied stripper with plastic and waited overnight.  The stripper took off one layer of latex paint.  So I applied a second coat and wrapped the panels in plastic and waited 18 hours.  The stripper took off another layer of latex paint, but the 3 layers of oil-based paint underneath was intact.  I had to repeat this process 4 more times and used 3 quarts of the stripper before the paint was completely removed.  This was quite costly, made a tremendous mess that I had to live with for almost a week, and during the process I regretted having started the project.

If you are taking off one layer of latex paint this stripper is fine.  For anything else, I think another poduct is needed.

My first reaction was disappointment. The case material lead me to expect a cheap, imported single-use tool.

For reader information: I used mainly 1 5/8" to 4" wood screws and bolts. I have not yet tested this drill with masonry or on metal.

The driver is lightweight, about the same as my Makita impact driver, but with less battery bulk.

I couldn't tell any difference between battery life in the Makita or the ACDelco and was glad they included a second battery. By the time I ran out of juice at the site, the next battery was ready to go.

I apologize for not timing the run time for this review, but now that I think about it, there was no delay between switching batteries and the amount of up time I experienced in the switch.

The most enjoyable advantage of this tool was its weight distribution. Overhead work was easy and I noticed that wrist fatigue was much less than my Makita or my Ryobi standard drill.
summary: Except for the case, this is outstanding!

I refinished my basement and added additional lighting and used some Insteon dimmers.  I had an old light switch at the top of the stairs that lead to the basement that would no longer work for me so I bought the RemoteLinc to wirelessly control my basement lights from the top of the stairs.

My plan was to remove the existing switch from the outlet box and then screw this bracket into it.  This way I wouldnt have a useless dead switch in the wall and wouldnt have to repair the drywall.  The problem with that is this bracket provides zero front-to-back stability when you operate the RemoteLinc switch.  It relies on the RemoteLinc resting flat against the drywall for that.

I ended up making it work by hot-gluing the switch to the bracket and then screwing it in.  Wont be as easy to charge the battery but luckily they last pretty long so it's not a big deal.  Given this purpose is not what it's designed for I couldn't go less than 3 stars, but it just doesnt make sense that they couldn't make a bracket that would allow for either mounting option.
summary: Won't work as bracket to replace existing switch in existing electrical box.

reviewText: gift

The Woods 041708 8-Outlet Electronics Energy-Saving Surge Protector is one of those electronic devices in which you don't really know how well it does until you have a lesser product fail under the same conditions. Thankfully, I don't really know yet.

The packaging tells me:
- 2700 Joules Surge protection
- 8 Grounded outlets
- 2-transformer outlet to fit large adapter plugs without blocking use of other outlets
- Protected and ground LED indicators
- Lighted Reset (on/Off) power and built-in resettable 15A Circuit breaker switch

What I'm certain of is that it is well-designed to allow use of all eight outlets at once. There's enough space. I also know when it is live (a light is on). And I can reset it easily.

I'm using this to plug in my TV, a DVD player, and a variety of stereo equipment, as well as a charger for my laptop.

--Brockeim

What you need to do is put a thin film of plumbers grease on the gaskets of the filter, the spout and the o-ring seal of the main unit so when you hand tighten it there will be no leaks at all. You can also use a Culligan filter wrench to open it up for replacing the filter. You can get both at your local hardware store for cheap.

After having several "jumper cable storage bags" I went for years without having one. I had tried various vinyl bags,  that was little more than useless.  Needless to say,  my cables were hanging on whatever was available in my home garage. After recently seeing this bag on Amazon,  It seemed well made and reviews were also good,  so I ordered one to try it out.  After receiving this bag, I checked it out thoroughly to be sure it was adequately made & strong enough to hold my heavy duty,  high amp,  cables securely.  I cleaned the blue cables with some excess auto cleaner and a new green nylon kitchen scouring pads ,  then stretched them out to dry,  by clamping each end to fence to thoroughly dry.  I then put a  little of the auto wax on  to make them more manageable. It really cleaned them and was easier to manage them as well. After two hours,  I neatly rolled them up and placed them in the new 69000 Cable Bag.
Would recommend this bag as being the best one I've owned.
summary: A nice,  heavy duty,  canvas  jumper cable storage bag,  that can easily hold a 18' length of #2 gauge jumper cable set!

reviewText:
I'm rather torn about what kind of review to give this. For the price it's a decent tool, however it has some issues. First, don't try using it until you've set the spacing between the end of the tool and the little die that the connector fits into. If the die is too far out you'll break your connector. If it's too far in you won't get a good crimp. To set the spacing take another piece of cable that has already been crimped, slip it into the tool, and then unscrew the die until it is snug in the connector. Then tighten the locking nut.

The second issue is the cutter. It's worthless. Don't even bother trying to use it. Just use some regular strippers or linemans pliers.

Third, you have to squeeze really REALLY hard to get it to set the connector properly. It works, just be prepared to squeeze the heck out of it. My wife probably couldn't use this tool just because of the strength needed to properly set the connector. It doesn't have much mechanical advantage.

Having said that, it does the job and it's the least expensive coax compression tool I could find. If you're only going to use it occasionally, then it's a fine tool. But don't buy this if you're going to be crimping connectors every day. Invest in a better tool.
summary: Good for occasional use, but definitely not for the pros.

I am glad that I bought this fan.  I was worried that for the low price it would be junk, but it is not.  The housing is good quality and it moves a lot of air.  No problems with it yet.

Compared to some of the 6" sunleaves wind tunnel fans I have this is all most just as nice.  The hydrofarm fan is wired externally, is a little less bulky and is a little quieter than a wind tunnel.  It has very basic mounting brackets compared to the wind tunnel.  The wind tunnel also comes with rubber washers for quieter operation when you mount it to a wall or the ceiling.  In my opinion I felt the washers do not help with noise coming through the floor.  I now hang all my fans with bungee cords and have no noise coming through the floor.  In my case the mounting brackets are pointless and I do not use them.

If this fan lasts, it is a great buy.  I found this fan at almost half the price as the 6" wind tunnel.  It has performed equally with the wind tunnel and I like the design better.  The external wiring could be a pro or con.  If it was wired internally it would be perfect for me, but it also leaves an easy option for direct wiring to anyone who may want that.
summary: Great fan at a great price
