I have been in the electronics business all my adult like, and have seen many different vendors of parts and their various qualities. When I saw that this product uses the CREE led, no further sales pitch was necessary. Among a busload of led makers, CREE pioneered the high power led and still leads the pack...it's the Rolls-Royce of leds. I have a small pocket flashlight, I believe made from this same part. It is about the size of a pack of life savers- I call it my "Holy Sh*t" flashlight because everyone is stunned by how much light it produces. Same deal with this headlight. Seriously, don't look into the end of this thing, or let children do so. I'm kind of surprised that the company didn't include the SOS function in the led driver, but for $20 I'll let that go. For those griping about it not coming with batteries, it is much better to know you have fresh batteries...you never know how long something has been on the shelf.

I needed an inexpensive light for my office that could provide fill-in or ambient light in the room, and could maybe be used as a spot upon occasion. This lamp fits that bill. It's easy to assemble and adjustable as described. I suspect that it's best to adjust to the way you want and to leave it sitting in that configuration, rather than adjusting it upward and downward all the time. Since that's the way I plan to use it (sitting in a single adjusted configuration) this is fine with me.

These things are super bright so don't even bother looking at the K charts trying to decide what brightness level you want because I promise you they WILL exceed what you thought and be much much brighter than you dreamed. They are just very powerful.

I mean this is the way of the world now because they are cheap, never burn out, burn about as much electricity as a night light, and are super bright.

But if you get anything over 3000 K you are going to have much brighter lights than you think.  And it's going to be much whiter than you think.

 Now I have can lights and I have tons of them like 12 in each room so for me it was a real issue and I had to keep getting lesser and lesser until I was down to 3000 and even then it was too bright for my wife.

If you only have like one big ceiling light then it probably won't be an issue for you but for cans? Just be careful!!
summary: Great lights but be warned if you have can lights!

reviewText:
Pretty happy with the results so far (one year).  My main reasons for applying the product to my driveway are as follows.  A section of downspout empties onto my driveway, which after 22 years has caused some erosion and spalling.  Also, in the spring, I have noticed evidence of spalling due to winter freezing.  Hopefully the hardening and sealing will mitigate further damage.  Also, I like to pressure wash my driveway (1900 Psi electric unit), and my thought was that hardening the concrete may mitigate erosion from pressure washing.

Hard to tell how much protection the product has provided. But you can definitely tell that much less water is absorbed.  When I first put the product down, water would bead up.  But after a year, I don't really notice this anymore.  The two attached pictures demonstrate how much dryer treated concrete stays relative to untreated. In the first picture, which was taken on a wet/rainy day, you can see three distinctly different shades of concrete.  The leftmost section hasn't been pressure washed for many many years and was not treated with the product.  The two rightmost sections were pressure washed last year, but only the far right section was treated with the product.  The treated section looks almost completely dry.  The next image shows the same areas on a dry day.  There is almost no difference in appearance between the treated/untreated sections when dry.  It will be interesting to see after a while whether the treated section resists dirt/grime better than the untreated.

If I were to do it again, I would be more careful to:

1) Do a better job masking off areas that I don't want sealed.  The instructions say that it doesn't change the appearance of the concrete.  That is true when the concrete is dry, but when it gets wet, areas that are sealed stay drier and appear brighter.  Where the driveway meets the curb concrete, I must have accidentally stepped on a section of concrete that I wasn't planning on sealing, and when it rains, you can see the boot print.  I used a piece of sheet metal as a shield when I was spraying the section of my driveway near an exposed section of my garage slab and house brickwork. However, there was still some splatter, which you can make out when it rains.
2) Not over apply. I bought two gallons to treat a little less than 1000 sq^2 feet. I probably didn't need that much. Once you apply the product, the sealing properties will quickly take effect, making it difficult for the concrete to take in more product. I guess I didn't read the instructions closely enough to realize that over applying can cause discoloration. You can't notice anything when the concrete is dry, but when it is wet, you can clearly make out some sections where I probably over applied and didn't pull back the excess. Hopefully this evens out over time.

For some reason, I didn't fully appreciate the extent of the sealing properties. I guess I figured it was mostly a densifier. I cleaned the concrete very well, but some sections where some bit of clay soil found its way back onto the driveway, I think the orange/red class got sealed into the concrete. I couldn't pressure wash it off.
summary: Pretty happy with the results so far (one year)

Update 1/25//2015: I don't take back what I've said below (except that I never did replace this lamp!), however, I found a way last night to mitigate the problem of changing bulbs (after my wife cut her thumb trying to remove a burnt out bulb). If you have a rubber jar lid removal pad similar to this: (4 Pack) Round Multi-Purpose Jar Gripper Pad Bottle Lid Opener (Colors May Very) , you can get the job of changing a bulb done. Hold the pad tightly against the flat face of the bulb, push in hard, and twist the bulb counterclockwise. After a short struggle, it comes out! Take the new bulb and put a small mark on it from a sharpie pen or whathaveyou--this mark to coincide with one of the two posts on the bulb's base. That way you can maneuver the bulb into position with both posts in the two receiving holes. Then take the rubber pad, press the bulb hard while turning it clockwise, and it will then catch and remain in place until next time. It's a lot to do just to change a bulb isn't it? Terrible design, because you can't easily change the bulbs. I just spent 20 frustrating minutes, and gave up, am looking for a replacement and see this turkey being sold, hence my warning review. Problem is, there is no finger room between the shade and the bulb. The bulb has two prongs that fit into two slots; you have to turn the bulb to lock it into position. It is extremely difficult to get the two prongs into the larger part of the slots, because you cannot grab the bulb with your fingers, you have to play games with it (does anyone remember those old puzzle boxes where you had to shake and turn a small enclosed box so you could get a series of BB's into the correct holes and not bounce them out again?). If they redesigned it so the shade came off so you could replace the bulbs, I would give it a 5 star, it's beautiful and works well. Just don't expect to change the bulbs without an enormous hassle!! BTW, my wife just spent another 10 minutes and got the bulb in, God bless her. But I will still buy something else. Hope this admitted rant will help someone else!
summary: Can't change bulbs without a hassle

It's made by a company called TAYLOR, not Smith and Wesson. I don't understand the thinking putting the S&W name on a product not manufactured by them.

Good quality overall. There's a shoulder strap with a snap to hold the knife in the scabbard. The handle isn't terribly long, but it's serviceable and made out of some kind of grooved rubberized material so it won't slip when it's wet with sweat or blood or whatever. Has a small lanyard hole with a metal grommet, nice touch. Put a strap in the lanyard hole, like one of those useless cell phone straps. You don't want the knife knocked out of your hand, right?

Comes with both edges nicely sharpened. Overall a good looking, functional fixed-blade knife. A useful tool for simple cutting or potentially for some late-night parking lot social work. Better safe than sorry.

The good:
* Colors are well-saturated and pure.  The blue is *really* blue, almost to the point of being near-UV.
* The remote works well.  It's got enough range to adjust lights from across the room.  Yet it's not SO sensitive/strong as to prevent you from controlling individual lights if you have more than one in the same room.
* Great form factor.  These are shaped and sized like incandescent lights, not ginormous CFLs.
* They reach full brightness immediately, unlike CFLs.
* The remote lets you select several different colors directly.
* The color-mixing function lets you select a range of colors that, for all intents and purposes, is infinite.  This is a feature most other multicolor LEDs cannot boast, especially at this price point.  Although...

The not-so-good:
* The color mixing function is a little awkward.  You'll get the hang of it, but you'll wish the interface was a little better developed.  I'd have gladly paid an extra $2 or so for a remote with buttons dedicated to turning up/down each color independently, rather than having to go to "RGB function."
* LED lighting remains an auxiliary, not a primary, light source.  These bulbs are not bright enough to be the primary lighting in a room (unless cost is no object and you're willing to build/buy a six-bulb fixture to house several bulbs).  As accent and mood lighting, they're good.  If you need high lux...not so good.

The bad:
* Nothing, really.  These are nifty little lights.
summary: Nice Colors, But Not Too Bright

reviewText:
Some large router bits are rated only for 11,000 RPM's. If you have a 3hp router that is just single speed, it is probably 22,000+ RPM's. So if you want to use those larger bits without shattering them, you need a speed control.

This speed control works like a charm. You plug the grounded speed control into the wall, and the router into the speed control. You can change the setting on the speed control to off, full speed, or variable speed. The variable speed setting is controlled by the dial. It works like a charm, you can wind down RPM's low enough to make the router useless if you wanted.

Doesn't work with my porter cable speedmatic 3-1/4hp router. That is more the routers fault though.

It appears to be made in the US.

Hope that helps

The Miter Saw Station (without a saw attached) also makes a pretty fair work table. It has a very substantial metal frame underneath.  You clamp this frame in the JawHorse jaws. Not much else to say -- the installation is about the same as that for any external wall fixture.

If you're attaching it to vinyl siding (which is the most common scenario in my opinion), you will need these two items:
* Arlington 8141-1 Vertical Siding Lamp Mounting Kit (check your siding offset first; This one is 1/2")
* Arlington 8100LP-1 MEGA Siding Plate (goes right over the previous item)

You need the above two items (especially the 8141 or something similar) for a code-compliant installation, especially if there is not a proper junction box in your wall to attach the base of the lantern to.
Do NOT attach it directly to the wall with nothing behind it (e.g. if you have a piece of Romex wire simply sticking out of a hole in the wall) -- that's a violation of the National Electrical Code, and is unsafe.

Using the Arlington 8141 or something similar should be an adequate substitute for a junction box (check with a local inspector or an electrician first though, as this may vary from one jurisdiction to another).
Advice: After attaching the mounting bracket to the wall (or, to be exact, to the junction box or a siding adapter), firmly attach the bare grounding wire to the grounding screw on the bracket first; that way it has something to dangle on while you are connecting the white and the black wires.

I bought this to replace the kitchen faucet that predates our ownership of the house, which had started to leak all over the counter every time it was used. Purchased on a Monday morning, the 2-day shipping estimate (Amazon Prime) was for Friday because of a possible "1 to 2 days for processing". The faucet arrived on Tuesday, beating Amazon's own best-case scenario! Removal of the old faucet was the real nightmare, but once done, the install of this faucet was surprisingly simple. They even include a tool that allows you to easily tighten the nut that holds it down without struggling with a wrench in that really cramped space. Much of the time savings was probably due to that tool. I don't care much for the fact that the nut is plastic though - I would have preferred something metal. The faucet is reasonably solid on the sink after tightening the nut down, but it's also not that difficult to grab the base and forcibly move it. I'll probably have to go back under the sink and try to tighten the nut a little more. Other than the plastic nut, the only other thing that bothers me a little is that the removable faucet head is plastic while everything else is metal. I suppose this may be for weight purposes - a heavier faucet head may not return back as easily. At any rate, I liked it enough to splurge a little more and purchase the Moen 77200CSL AquaSuite Filtering Kitchen Faucet for the port left open by the old faucet's sprayer. They look great together, and both were installed with zero additional required parts -- only what was supplied in the box.
summary: Overall works great, couple of minor things I'd change

I hesitated to spend so much on a toilet seat, but I have no regrets at all. It is beautifully designed and manufactured. The soft-close and removable features both work great, as other reviewers have said. The seat is at least as comfortable as the padded seat I had before it, and it's light but very strong; I weigh almost 300 pounds, and the closed lid doesn't give at all when I sit on it (I've sat on some plastic seats that felt almost like a trampoline). By the way, the seat fits and works fine on my old generic toilet from the 1950s, so the toilet doesn't have to be either a Kohler or new.

One small thing that I didn't notice until I started using it is the very nicely designed hand-hold at the front edge of the lid. The lid sticks out just a little bit farther than the seat at the front edge only, which provides a perfect lifting point for your fingers. It's a small and subtle design feature that makes a nice difference from any other seat I've used.

The only caution I'd pass on is to be careful when you install the seat about getting the little square black posts aligned correctly. They mate with the hinge latch in only one orientation, and there's no mention of them in the installation instructions. The seat comes with them correctly oriented inside the hinge, but it's hard to keep them there while you mount the seat because you have to unlatch the hinges to do it. A reviewer of the round version of this seat had complained about this and about the poor installation instructions that don't help at all. So before I took the black posts out of the hinges for mounting I checked which way they were facing, and everything went fine.

The one negative is that the modes seem a little "finicky".  I think part of this is that the modes include a lockout capability, where you can set the light to not turn on, to prevent accidentally turning it on, but it's not too difficult to put the light into that lockout mode. reviewText: Very good.

I have never replaced a garbage disposal, though I am pretty handy doing simple electrical, plumbing and other basic home repair jobs. Something like a garbage disposal seems so complicated, but the instructions are really for a homeowner. Do you know any plumber that reads the directions? The tools needed are pictured in the manual: flashlight, tape measure, SEALANT, pencil, adjustable wrench, Phillips and flat screwdrivers, small stick between 3" - 12", hammer, adjustable pliers, and hacksaw. The hardest thing to find may be the stick which is used to punch out the plug on the dishwasher inlet (so you won't need the stick if you don't have a dishwasher).

I have had several garbage disposals in the various houses and apartments I have lived in. They all looked pretty much the same. I just removed the old 5/8 HP unit that started to leak oil and kept jamming for no apparent reason (the bearings?) The replacement Moen disposal is ... how do I say it ... beautiful to look at? It looks like a part from Star Trek - something Geordi La Forge might be installing while saying something in techno-babble on the Enterprise. Not that anyone will ever see it but you!

It is so quiet you won't hear ANYTHING if there is talking, music or background sound in the kitchen. No joke, I preferred the old unit in this regard because I got audible feedback as to when everything was done being ground up. The Moen comes with a 2-foot power cord with 3-prong standard wall plug. My prior home had an electrical outlet in the back of the cabinet that would accept such a plug, but in my current kitchen the disposal must be hard wired. I reused the old wires since the 2-foot cord would not be long enough (and I don't know if using such a cord would meet code).

You might imagine that the flange that supports the disposal under the sink would have several parts and be a little complicated. There are nine washers, gaskets, o-rings, flanges, etc. that nest in only one configuration but the instructions have a great diagram. Unfortunately, the flange that you see when you look into the sink is chrome and it comes with a chrome stopper / sink plug. Does anyone have a chrome sink? This would look awful, so I reused the old brushed nickel flange that matches the sink. That piece was special order when the plumber installed the sink and former disposal - both made by Kohler - the flange was designed to match the sink exactly.
summary: Easy Instructions for Homeowner Install - or Call Your Plumber

Sept 2013 Update** I now own (7) of these units, two of them being used outdoors near the pool.  I have had no quality issues with any of the locks and/or buttons. After 3 years I did have one lock that upon pushing in the code it would blink red, then green and would unlock as designed.. I did not realize for a week or two that this was the low battery indicator.  My husband would see the red and immediately start punching in the number again assuming he was at fault... Patience would have worked better :) I found it incredible that these locks would work that long on one battery.

We will never have anything but combination locks on our doors, they have certainly made life less cumbersome not having to carry keys.  New car doesn't require a key either.. what a change from the jailers set I use to carry.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

We have purchased five of the Schlage keypad deadbolts.  I had originally started with two  but after realizing how amazing convenient these would  be near the pool, I purchased additional  units.  I have six exterior doors so the chances of exiting one door to enter elsewhere is good.  The first three that I purchased were all keyed alike, I am not going to have the next two re-keyed as these are secondary doors that I most likely would never need to enter using a key.  The first units have been on my doors for 9 months with absolutely no issues.  Schlage also makes a auto locking keypad deadbolt that I plan on purchasing for my pool entry gate.

The convenience of taking the dog for a walk, or going to the mailbox while not having to worry about carrying a key has been great.  I find that I lock all my doors all the time since I never need to think ahead about locating keys.  This product makes things so easy, I have begun to give the deadbolts as gifts.

I live in a high ceiling house, where my wife can't reach the smoke detector if it comes on. While away from town, I received I distress call from her that the smoke detector went off while she was cooking, and since all the smoke detectors are connected, all seven of them started screaming at the same time. This went on for 30 or so minutes until the HVAC and the opened windows did their job. After this dreadful event, I had to make some changes.

The Nest Protect installation is a breeze (be it for the wired or battery powered). The only thing to watch out if you're installing the wired version is to cut the power for smoke detector and test it with a voltage tester. After that, as with all Nest products, installation to your account is a breeze. Now, we don't have to worry about the smoke detector. As it should be. This thing tests itself during hours you are not home, so you don't forget to test it every month (which never happens, let's be real). If there is smoke, it warns you with a nice lady voice instead of the obnoxious, painful to your eardrums alarm. You can turn it off by pressing the button on it or through the app on your phone, tablet or computer. It even tells you where the smoke was detected. And if this wasn't enough, it works seamlessly with the other Nest products if you already own those. Helps with presence detection for the thermostat, turns off your HVAC if smoke is detected, works with the rest of the Works with Nest products, etc.

This is really, one very fine product.
summary: This changed our cooking life and sanity

I mixed eight 80lb bags of concrete and the bag didn't show any signs of wearing out.  It was easy to dump the concrete out where I needed it, and cleanup was easy (I just put it in the trash).

Some suggestions:
- If the type of concrete you are using is available in 50lb or 60lb bags, use those instead of the 80lb bags, as the 80lb bags are difficult to handle and mix.  Despite mixing for much longer than recommended in the instructions, every bag I mixed had some dry spots in it that I had to fix by raking the concrete after I had poured it out.
- Tie the bag near the top so there is plenty of space in the bag for the concrete to slosh around.
- I wanted a dry mix but found it was too difficult to get it consistent.  I gave up and just went with a medium wet mix.
- You WILL get dirty. No matter how tight you close the bag, some water will escape when you first start mixing.
- The instructions tell you to rock the bag side to side. I found that this wasn't enough, I had to lay the bag down and knead it like I was making bread.
- Lay an old towel on the ground to make sure the bag doesn't get ripped.

If I was doing a larger job I think I'd buy this: http://www.amazon.com/Scepter-04239-7-Gallon-Odjob-Mixer/dp/B000BPK766, as I was pretty much worn out after mixing 8x80lb bags.

The gas tube on an AR does not usually get too dirty, but I still clean it every so often anyway. I do not lube it after cleaning, instead I run some acetone or 99% isopropryl alcohol through it. The acetone or alcohol will completely evaporate leaving no residue. I have heard too many stories about lube just collecting dirt in a gas tube and that they do not necessarily need to be cleaned. I have never had an issue with my technique, and I hate dirty weapons, so I clean it.

You can make your own choices (obviously) about clean/don't clean. If you do clean, give some thought to not lubing the tube.
summary: Do gas tubes even need cleaning?

reviewText: Wonderful product.

I find that I'm always running short on outlets and usb charging ports. Power strips are cheap enough, but they're just so ugly, and when I load them up with AC adapters, they have a tendency to tip over on their sides from the weight. They also don't normally have usb charging ports. Well, I found this on Amazon, and I have to say, I'm impressed. It has a solid feel and weight to it and it's nice and wide, since the outlets are arranged in a grid instead of a straight line like normal power strips. I would have preferred if it had at least 2 more outlets, but I can load up all the plugs on this and not worry about it tipping over. Plus there's plenty of space for your bigger AC adapters since the plugs are nicely spaced apart. There's 4 usb ports for charging your electronics, which is great because now I don't need to plug in all those AC adapters for my portable devices, which leaves the outlets free for other things. It's also black so I can put it on top of my desk and it won't be an eyesore like a white power strip would be. Overall, I like it, and so far, it's working great.

I received this item for free or at a discount in exchange for an honest review. This is my true opinion on the product and hasn't been influenced by this fact.
summary: It has a solid feel and weight to it and it's nice and wide

reviewText:
The 30 year old, decrepit, flickering overhead light fixture in my hobby room finally died on me, and for various reasons, I am unable to have it replaced at this time. What's one to do in this situation? Buy a portable work light!

This Snap On LED work light is just what I needed. It is light, easy to carry and has a nice little stand. It swivels up and down, allowing you to direct the light the way you need to. And best of all, it is very bright. I have the light pointed slightly upwards in my little 9x10 room and it fills the entire space with enough light to get done what I need to do. Yes, there may be some shadows cast and it doesn't hit light in every single area, but honestly that does not matter to me.

The one thing to note, which may or may not be good depending on your situation, is that the light switch on the back is kind of hard to reach and covered with a protective cover, which can make it quite hard to switch on and off. I personally get stiff joints so this is a downside for me, but I do manage. Aside from that small quibble, I do very much like the light and easily recommend it to anyone looking for a convenient, portable light source.
summary: Very nice light with one potential drawback

reviewText: This tool is durable, and feels well made.  I use it on all of our Boy Scout camp outs.

This product is the perfect fit in our kitchen, which we have been remodeling this spring. This replaced a standard outlet mounted inside a bookshelf-style under-cabinet with no doors where we used to keep our recipe books. Because recipe books seem less and less definitive all the time in this age of new technology, we have actually saved a lot of space by simply installing this 2 USB outlet and plugging in an iPad or iPhone for our cooking needs. This is also perfect for plugging in an iPhone, tablet or e-Reader simply just for charging purposes (as one can never have enough charging stations), and I think we will this style of outlet pop up more and more as time goes by. I should mention the product does not have a cover plate with it, but that's not a big deal because they are cheap and a lot of people have custom colors or designs for the cover plates in their homes anyway and want them all to match. I cannot comment on ease of installation because a close friend of ours is an electrician and installed this for us in no time. From reading the reviews of others, however, it seems to be pretty straight-forward and hassle-free for the DIY crowd. Buy with confidence - this is a great product for the modern dweller!
summary: Excellent product for the modern dweller

The lamp is easy to turn on and off but the movement of the arms/springs is a bit tight and will take some getting used to. The hardware that attaches to the desk or table seems to be strong and works well on my oak drawing table. reviewText:
UPDATE: After several weeks of not being able to connect this device to the WiFi in my home or the app on Android I am lowering my rating. I've spoken to tech support a couple times and the last time I spoke with someone who was the expert on this product and the WiFi connection and after more than 30 minutes he gave up on ideas on why it is not connecting. Keep in mind that I have three of these fans and this is the only one not connecting and that I have a dozen smart home products connecting in my home. I tried two different WiFi networks. It is clear to me that there is a glitch in this one. So while it looks great, I cant recommend it until there is a fix.

After having this up and running for a week I'm ready to say this fan has some issues even though it looks fantastic.

INSTALLATION: This was easy as heck. All the new fans I've done over the last six months (three from different brands) all have the hanging bar making this super easy. Wiring also worked great with a dual panel switch set. I was up and running in about 30 minutes and that was taking my time. This model wobbles something fierce and I can't get the leveling kit to work through it (unlike other models). It may have to do with the shape of the blades.

QUALITY: This model is much nicer looking than others. It has a real glass light cover and the housing looks more solid than it feels. The curve of the blades is really distinctive.

RUNNING: It moves air well. A big issue I had was that it smelled like it was burning when I first started using it. And it gets hot to the touch on the top of the main housing. I called customer service (twice, because they didn't seem real interested in helping me on the first call) and was assured that it was burning off a "coating on the motor" and that I needed to run it for 24 hours in each direction. Well, I ran it for a couple days in the same (summer) direction and now the smell is gone. I would have liked a head's up on that. (And a more helpful rep.) Also, this is louder than other models. I think it is because of the blade twists. It wobbles and I can hear it more than others.

WIRELESS: Is ridiculously hard. The correct app is in the instruction manual for Android. Even with it, connecting is a pain in the butt. I have three different Hunter smart fans and this one has still never paired. It said it did, but then went away and won't work. You have to add the fan by scanning a QR code, put in your WiFi and then pass code. Then you hope it goes through. Most of the time in my experience it did not go through. I'm not a newbie in this field either. This is poor connectivity. Once (if) you get it set up you can turn off the stupid audible beep for light and speed adjustments as well as turn on dimming on the light through the app. (You can dim the light with the remote by holding the light button and it will cycle through brightness. You may have to push and hold both up and down arrow on the remote to make that work.) Also, I really hate that this doesn't work with Alexa or Wink. Why do all these companies keep making proprietary items? It's like a door company that keeps making you cut a different size hole in your wall to use it. Just make a standard and keep it up. I dislike the wireless on this.

OVERALL: For a $300-400 fan this was a let down. It was easy to install but not easy to set up. It looks good but up close looks cheap. It doesn't play with other smart home systems (on Android). My old fan cost me less than $100 on sale and it lasted 8 years and is now working perfectly at a buddy's house. I just don't see a reason for this cost. So for now, I wouldn't recommend it.
summary: Looks Great, Doesn't Run As Well IMO

reviewText: good

This little Jet bandsaw came yesterday.  It was well packaged and arrived in good condition.

Here is the best part: It is every bit as good as they say it is.
It was EASY to assemble and the instructions were great.
I was not missing anything, the unit was preassembled in the main, and after about 1 hour I had it working quite well.
I tried it out on a current project and loved it. (But it is very limited in use.)
This is well worth the money, and I think that anyone buying it will be pleased with the value.  I appreciated so much the fact that the basic heart of the unit is preassembled, and obviously, had been checked out for basic function before it ever left the factory.

If you need a real saw with a deeper throat and higher cut range capability, this will NOT be everything you had hoped for when you ordered it.  The disappoinment is the highth off of the table for cutting.  Example: If you have a cut of wood taller than 4" to cut or trim, this will not fit under the guide: it can just barely handle a 4" cut. To be "really" full service useful, it needs to be able to cut at least a 5" to 6" corbel for a fireplace mantle end.... otherwise.... for the money, it is a good cute little unit.
It has all the features of a larger more expensive saw, with roller bearing blade guides and roller thrust bearings, yet at this homeowners price.
Enjoy
summary: Nice little band saw for the money!

This has been my everyday carry knife since it was introduced.  It was the first SOG knife I've owned, and I'm very favorably impressed.  Like all good tools, the Aegis has become an extension of my body.  Its use is now so completely wired into my brain that it's close to an autonomous function.  I'd have about as much trouble describing how to open and close the Aegis, as I'd have describing how to breathe.  The blade deploys very quickly and after a delightful bit of flicking, the operation becomes very reliable and second nature.  It's in your pocket.  A second later, you're cutting stuff.  I opened it in a restaurant once and my brother smiled.  I asked what was so funny, and he said the woman behind me was startled at the rapid display of a knife, even though I wasn't menacing anyone and was calm and nonthreatening in my demeanor.  However, if you ever did need it for defense, it's capable of being intimidating... and a lot more.

Almost every detail of this knife is perfect.  The body is very light and some people complain that it makes the knife nose heavy.  Maybe, but it never bothered me.  It feels great in my hand, with a lot of control, for cutting heavy cardboard, or delicate tasks that are more often a job for an Xacto.  The jimping is perfect.  The shape of the blade is perfect for my varied uses.  The shape of the handle and the fit in my hand is perfect.  The textured rubber inserts... perfect.

I've never liked liner locks.  I LOVE the ARC lock.  It's brilliant and works very well.  I subconsciously thumb the ARC lock and fold the back of the blade against the back of my thigh to close it on the way back into my pocket.  There's no chance of inadvertently cutting myself in the process, unlike a liner lock that requires me to reach across the blade to unlock it.

Even the tiniest details are well considered, such as the SOG pocket clip that carries the folded knife deeply, securely and discretely.  The pocket clip works in conjunction with the grippy rubber inserts in the handle to provide the right amount of grip to keep the knife in my pocket, but it comes out quickly and easily when I want to use it.  The folded shape is somewhat pear shaped and acts similarly to a watch fob to stay oriented well in pockets of all sizes, although mine is well constrained and secure in a narrow knife pocket.

The blade is easy to sharpen and it stays sharp a long time.

About the only complaint I have, and it's a minor complaint, is the deep belly on the blade (which is great!) results in a notch between the blade and the handle.  Sometimes when I'm slashing away with the full length of the blade, sheet goods or cord can catch between the blade and handle.

I thought about disassembling the knife and removing the safety lock, as I never use the safety and I don't want the safety to accidentally switch on just before I need it.  This happened once or twice the first week I had the knife but hasn't happened in the last 2-3 years, so I never bothered with it.

I have not babied this knife at all, and it still looks almost new, and that includes the tough TiNi black finish on the blade and the black finish on the clip, screws, etc.

If I ever lost this knife, I'd immediately buy another.  In fact, I thought about buying one or two to put in a drawer as a backup in case SOG ever discontinues it and I lose mine.  I'd be greatly inconvenienced to be without the use of this knife for even a few days.  It's become a part of me.

reviewText: I just purchased this unit and so far it stands high above the standard version.  Two nice things about this driver are the charge indicator LED's and the light timer.  If I see one light on the charge indicator I know it's time to grab the other battery and I can plan a stopping point in my work.  I can squeeze the trigger momentarily and the light will stay on for a few seconds giving me enough time to navigate working in a dark or confined area.  The brushless motor is powerful, quiet and doesn't produce sparks like a standard motor which is the big failure point for any D.C. motor.  Only time will tell if this product will outlast the standard version. All of the other components that make this unit work have to be durable and reliable.

I purchased these numbers to compliment the white and gold color scheme of my Postal Pro Hampton All-in-One Mailbox Kit in White. It paired wonderfully. This mailbox is not carried by Amazon, but you can find it easily enough at one of your big home improvement stores, just Google it, highly recommended. The end result looks like I spent hundreds, and it's worlds apart compared to what you normally see on the street.

These numbers aren't a stamped brass deal as I perceived in the pictures, yet I wasn't disappointed when they arrived. The backing of the number is gold, with a domed overlay of hard yet pliable, clear, jelly-like plastic. This gives the numbers a light catching and concentrating jewel effect. Application was a cinch, I used scotch tape to provide a level guide so I could apply them centered. Item packaging was well done, and assured you had clean, fresh plastic to work with. Care must be taken when removing the backing so as not to stretch or distort the number. It's best to bend the backing when you get it started and let it roll off, rather than pull it off, but the adhesive was spot-on. I know they will last for years. After applying them in the sunset today, I must admit I looked at it more than a few times to admire my handiwork

One caveat: I don't think these numbers are as legible at night as the flat white number on black background stick-ons. They're perfectly legible if you slowed as you approached the mailbox, but not so much from afar. Headlights don't bounce back because of the domed effect, but they're probably just as visible as the flat black number on copper/bronze stick-ons.
summary: Clean, ritzy look. I have the best looking mailbox on the block!

reviewText:
This is an item that started life as a good idea but lost its way. The concept is that it is a Decora-style plate with no visible screws showing. Nothing new there, those have been around for many years. What makes it different is that it doesnt use any screws at all. Instead, you slip a plastic subplate over the screws that hold the switch/outlet in place and then you snap the front wallplate to it, which is supposed to result in a smooth clean installation.

These plates would be ideal for contractors in tract homes because they install very fast and don't require extra time to install the additional screws it usually takes for wallplates. For a homeowner who wants to replace one or two plates only, there really isn't any time savings because they still have to back the existing screws out to fit the subplate around them.

The idea isn't all that bad and should rate a positive review. But there are a few negatives that erase the postives:

1. High on that list is that, unlike the usual Decora wallplates, these are not adjustable. In a perfect scenario they will look fine but if your wall surface around the outlet isn't perfect you can end up with a wallplate that isn't flush with the switch/outlet. And theres no way to compensate for it. Even a tiny error can result in a sloppy-looking installation.

2. The plastic used is very flimsy. That may not be a big issue when used behind furniture, but if you are using these on an outlet or wall switch that gets used a lot you may get annoyed how much the wallplate creaks and flexes.

3. But the number one reason this product fails a top-rated rank is price. One would think that being only two pieces of thin plastic and the cost savings of no screws that these would cost less (substantially less) than Decora wallplates from Lutron or other brands. But no, they cost as much or more than the style that uses hidden screws. So you are getting less but not saving money. Thats not a good deal.

I made the mistake of trying to use this wallplate on an outlet thats only about 5 away from another outlet that has the standard hidden screw Decora wallplate on it and by comparison this one looks cheap.  As a bottom line recommendation I would recommend these for contractors looking to save time when building/remodeling an apartment or tract home. I would not recommend them to homeowners who are after a finished look in their home.
summary: Is this as good as the Decora wallplate you are used to?

reviewText: Of all the small flashlights I have owned, this one shines the brightest.  It is made of metal, and has a push button on the end, to turn it off and on.  If you push the button firmly, the flashlight comes on.  If you press it softly, you can select from four other operating modes:  medium, low, strobe, and SOS.  This flashlight comes with a well made,  electric charger, to recharge the battery when it runs low.  This flashlight is the perfect size for purse or pocket, or glove box.  The only thing I don't particularly care for is the uncommon size of battery that it uses.  It is bigger than a AA but smaller than a C, so if you need to replace the battery, you'll have to order another one.  I was pleased to be given the opportunity to evaluate and review this flashlight during a promotional launch.  Opinions shared are my own and your experiences may differ.
summary: A very bright light from a small flashlight

reviewText:
After reading all of the reviews on this and similar products, I went with the Storm Shield (16ft), based on price.  Knowing that everyone else said the glue included with the kit was crappy, I tossed it and and got two tubes of heavy duty liquid nails.  It worked very well and was enough to do a 16ft run with about a 1/4 tube to spare.  I just used more on the ends, since several reviewers mentioned that the ends "curl up".  I installed this product in mid-October and the weather was fairly cool (low-60's), meaning the thick rubber of the Storm Shield was not easy to work with and indeed, since the product arrives rolled up in a box, even unrolling it flat overnight, with weight on each end, did not stop the ends from curling up again.  I ended up using a heat gun (think serious industrial blow dryer), and worked back and forth on both sides of the curled up rubber, about 8 inches away.  After about 5-7 minutes on each side, it made the rubber pliable enough to work out the curls, so it was totally flat when I moved it into position on the ground!  The heat gun did not burn, bubble or melt the rubber - but I was careful, checking it often.  Took the advice of other reviewers and bought a small bottle of etching liquid for the concrete, so that the glue would adhere to the concrete properly and this was a good call.  Finally, I used a high quality exterior caulk and did both sides of the Storm Shield, to help ensure no water could get underneath.  Also a good call.

This product has kept 90% of the water out and in my case it was really just in one corner of the garage that was the problem.  I'm happy with the purchase and would say if you add the heat gun (beg, borrow or steal), you should be good to go.
summary: New tip!  Use a heat gun, toss the glue that comes with it.

reviewText:
This is a whole house (2 or 3 people) filter unit with a shut off head on it that twists 30 degrees to either shut off the water going through the filter housing, or straight (as the photo shows) for normal operation.
I have been running one of these for the past 10+ years in Fort Mohave, Arizona (Hot and Dry).
The unit WILL NOT LAST 10 YEARS IN THIS CLIMATE. I can only speak of the climate I live in, but assume the results would be much the same unless you are living in paradise, and then you would be drinking from an artesian well
In the real world, you need at least one of these to stop the muck from getting into your house.
I woke up one day at three or four in the morning to walk the dog and had a gusher coming out of this filter housing, and running down the embankment. The housing had cracked. Replaced the housing with the cheaper opaque unit and two days later it sprang another leak out of the head.

My recommendation is to not get this unit with the shut off head (it is a pain in the rump) and instead, go for the AP802 at 45gpm (large house)or the AP801 at 20gpm which is closer to this AP101T at only 8gpm, or the AP11S or AP11T which is the one I am using at this time.

This unit will leak in three places: (1) The in and out fittings of which I had to finally use Permatex high performance thread sealant on the head input fitting threads, as the Teflon tape used on the other threads would not seal at this point.
(2) The plastic filter canister which (as stated) needs O-ring grease/new O-ring, or the canister may have a hairline crack in it. DO NOT OVER TIGHTEN THE CANISTER. (3) The stupid shut off head which ACTUALLY causes most of the problems, and can usually be fixed by unscrewing the flat head screw at the top, pulling the hand turn off, and replace the two (2) O-rings on the shaft. You can get O-rings that will work at someplace like Ace; just take your old ones with you to size.

You do need to have the capability to shut off the water to the unit to replace the filter, so just put in a simple ball valve since you are doing plumbing work anyway, or use your street shut off.

My original AP101T only lasted about 6 years, and when these things go (And they always go at three A.M.), you get a higher water bill, and if installed in the wrong place, water damage.

Also, all of this size filter housing use a Aqua Pure 63597174C O-ring that needs to be lubricated when installed; you can use electric grease, any O-ring lube, or Dow Corning 7 Release Compound which is what I use.
summary: Used over 10 years. Repair Instructions in review.

Loved the button. Loved the solid brass. The finish needed to be polished and buffed slightly. It was dingy when received.

I was impressed with the solid brass construction. This was a selling point for me. When I dislike is the plastic mount that the brass attaches too. You secure to the wall a plastic bracket first, then you slide the top of this button over the bracket and use a set screw on the bottom to secure it. They should have used a metal bracket in my opinion.

In addition this comes with a clear plastic backing (which is supposed to let light from the button illuminate the surround) which the instructions tell you to install before the mount bracket. In other words you put this clear plastic backing against the wall, then add the mount over it and screw both to the wall. The idea in my mind, behind the solid brass, was to make a lifetime button mount I would never have to change again. Adding all this plastic crap is going to (in my opinion) shorten the life and look of the product. I can just image in 5 years the clear plastic sun damaged and foggy looking or cracked. I opted to install it without the clear plastic backing and it looks great. The sunlight can't damage the plastic mount now either.
The battery did not last very long.
Works great, reliable, battery is more powerful and lasts a long time.
summary: more kick than the lower end model

I  received my Panasonic as a replacement for my loud Broan bathroom fan like many others. A friend of mine had recommended it for my masterbath as there is a door that enters right into the bedroom...and the fan was loud.  The demo was easy, i have fairly easy access to my attic, so installing the joist support was  very easy.  Is the install easy? That depends on your comfort level.  All I will say is for as thoughtful and well designed the product is....that's how poorly written the instructions are. I am pretty technically savvy and did the install myself....however I could see what all the reviewers were talking about... In any case the unit is sturdy, well designed and quiet, while moving a nice amount of air.  I have had the fan installed for a few weeks now and am very pleased.  The unit is all you need for an average sized bathroom,  I look forward to many years of great service.

I bought this blade to finish a fairly large tile job I started with a different blade. The first blade I was using came with my tile saw and had already seen some use. When I first started using this blade the difference between it and the original blade was night and day. It cut smooth and straight and there was considerably less effort needed to feed the tile. Toward the end of the job I could notice that the blade was no longer cutting as it did when I first mounted it. It was still better than the original blade but not like new.

The job I was doing as I said was fairly large, maybe 500 square feet, but the tile was also installed at a 45 and therefore required a lot of cutting.

This is only the second blade I've ever used, the other being the original, so I cannot say how it compares to other blades. It did get the job done though and though not as good as new it also likely has plenty more life in it.
summary: Worked really nice for a while.

For example, I was installing a ceiling fan with my father-in-law the electrician.  Got into a low-light situation because we'd disconnected the ceiling light. I felt 50% more handy and was 100% more useful to the guy who was struggling on top of the ladder in that moment.

I have used the D51275K finish nailer for a couple of years now on crown and base; casement; and have had no problems with it (or its Dewalt companion 18ga 51238K brad nailer, also excellent). It gets intensive use during trim-out phases and I have had only two jams that I can recall (neither one was the guns fault). The tools-free access to the firing head had the nails cleared quickly. The adjustable exhaust flow is a real plus, as is the the ease of depth adjustment. The gun loads easily and I have had no trouble at all finding nails for it. I have been able to locate all lengths in small to large lots on Amazon's web site. I have had virtually trouble-free operation, so I am at a real loss to explain the 'uneven' reviews from users! Perhaps some of the users need to read the manual of operation a little more closely? Perhaps some are using a different angle nail strip than spec'd? Perhaps the factory had a quality control problem for a while?? So far, I have not had any problems nailing even hardwood trims such as oak, but then, most of the trim has been with softwoods and compressed foam/synthetic products.

This nailer's light weight means less operator fatigue and more production. As an aside, the Dewalt (D51238K) 18ga brad nailer is perfect for smaller 'build-up' mouldings like cove, quarter rounds, etc. I have never experienced a single jam with the 18ga. although, admittedly, it doesn't get as intensive use as the 15ga.

Note: I purchased 'Grizzly's #H3401 Nail Gun Carrying Bag' from Amazons third-party vendor Grizzly. It is designed to carry framing nailers but notes that it will carry a couple of finish nailers. My Dewalt 15GA and 18GA finish nailers fit fine; the adjustable straps at the bottom of the bag secure the nailers tightly. The bag has hand-carrying handles and also a shoulder strap. I doubled over a large piece of cardboard to slip between the nailers to protect them from rubbing and banging against each other. Its a great way to transport and protect your nailers; both in one bag. Check it out.

reviewText: Nice

The Good:
The best feature of this lathe is that it is very light weight.  When I'm done turning, I unclamp the lathe from my workbench and put it on a shelf in the closet.  It takes up very little space, which is important to me since I live in a mobile home.

The variable speed control is also nice.  It's easy to dial in whatever speed you want for the type of wood and tools you are using.

The motor and tailstock bearings are very quiet.

The Bad:
Some compromises were made to allow the lathe to be so very light.

If you don't permanently mount this lathe on your workbench, then you must bolt it to a board which is clamped to a table or workbench when in use.

The tool rest is very small.  Even when turning a pen, you'll need to move the tool rest multiple times before you finish the project.

Putting moderate pressure on the tailstock end of an 8" spindle while turning will cause the tailstock to move.  You must use a very light touch on the tailstock end of your project to keep everything centered.  This makes larger projects, such as tool handles, quite challenging.

Summary:
If portability is critical for you, this is probably the most portable lathe on the market.  If portability is not critical for you, I'd suggest going with a more heavy-duty model.
summary: Good and Bad: It's a very light weight lathe

reviewText:
I like to keep a diverse knife collection and was giddy to try several Coast knives recently and found that this particular one is OK and lacks several key features to be competitive with superior, similarly priced knives.

When the FX414 arrived I took a good glance at it and realized a few things I did not like the first being no real way of clipping it on... well, anything.  There's no belt clip or pouch to secure it on oneself and it's sheer weight means that it will flop around in your pocket unless you're wearing really tight jeans and most guys don't.  While carrying it around it would flop from side to side and weigh down whatever I was wearing, especially if I sported shorts as it felt as though it was going to dig a hole through.

Another feature I did not like was the locking mechanism as it is a simple clicking lock that doesn't always engage.  This is a safety issue as an unsecured blade can fall back into place and over the very hand griping the handle.  It's not as though the blade is super sharp (another issue) but it's a little disconcerting.

Lastly, after you have clicked it into the open position, closing it requires precise unlocking of the same clicking mechanism and if you have large or shaky hands (my step-Dad has a tremor and couldn't make it work properly) it becomes too cumbersome to be a handy knife.

All in all, I have MUCH better luck with Gerber knives as they seem to be built better with more quick-convenience features in mind.

reviewText: This is a great lamp. Easy to set up, easy to use, easy to adjust the brightness to suit your need. I use it daily to read and just really love it.
Looks almost like a book so it blends well in a bookshelf. Flimsy lock.

Love the lamp, though I had a couple of minor issues.

The box the lamp comes in has a picture of a completely different lamp on the outside. I was told it is a generic box and when I opened it I was happily surprised to find the correct fan and light housing.

The installation documentation is a lovely booklet that turned out to be confusing until i realized it is for other lamps. I followed the single insert instruction sheet and it was all I needed to install.

I had read from comments here that the installation requires two people, a warning also repeated in the documentation, but I had no difficulty in doing it on my own.

My old lamp's electrical box seemed insufficiently sturdy - it wiggled quite easily- and was mounted into the side of a ceiling beam. Because the base of the new lamp is so large, a foot or more in diameter, I was able to center it under the beam and screw it directly into the wood.

The two person part seems to be the part where you lift the outer cover onto the already attached motor housing and hold it in place while you fasten the four holding screws. I instead used my jewelers screwdrivers as temporary nails by holding the cover in place while inserting them into the aligned screw holes. Then I was able to let go of the cover in place then replace the mini screwdrivers one by one with the approved screws.

The fan / light switch is pretty ingenious and installed easily as a replacement for my existing regular on/off switch.

There is one part I'm unsure of. The fan spins up and twice I've heard a tick tick as the fan hits something internally. It was easy to wiggle the light housing to get it to stop, but after about a week it tick-ticked again and required a second adjustment wiggle. Hopefully it won't come back.

I'm very pleased with my purchase .

reviewText: Excellent

Its a good filter, easy to install, made of lightweight plastic (a good thing because it will not make the shower pipe droop down like the old heavy ones did) and it completely eliminates all the smell of chlorine and everyone stopped complaining of dry itchy skin after I installed it.

The only tip I should pass along is that the you install a new one, do instal the hose and point the hose at the drain, as close as you can get to the drain) then slowly turn up the water. The first few seconds that the water is running it will throw out some carbon from this filter. The carbon is, of course, completely harmless but its particles are so small that will get trapped in the texture of your shower floor and leave a black mark. It eventually goes away but it might be noticeable to some people.

The other tip I can offer is that this is an effective filter but it clogs up easily. There are only two of us that use the one in the master bath and it only lasts 4 months (once it lasted 5 months, I got al excited but the next one only lasted 5 months again). I do wish that it lasted longer because I have having to recycle the perfect shell, but that is a small wish for future versions.

I highly recommend this unit if you have excessively chlorinated water in your shower.

Then I noticed that the new one (also from Nite-Ize) had a big blob of glass over the LED, so it was different. So I checked the Nite-Ize site, and found that one is rated at 1-watt, the other isn't.
So where the cheaper Nite Ize LRB-07-PR  (without the 1W at the end) is fine for walking the dog, I'm going to engrave DADDY'S MAGLITE on the one with the 1W bulb, so I know which one to take hunting.  I've already used it in the woods, and it gives me a nice feeling to know that this light is not going to quit. 5 stars, worth every penny.

reviewText:
I'm so happy with light.  First the fact it detects motion, second how bright it is, and third it's easy to hang anywhere.  I live in upper lower Michigan.  In the woods.  It is to say the least "dark"  We have our younger niece and nephew stay with us sometimes.  This past weekend was a 3 day stay over.  Although they are not really afraid of the dark, going to the bathroom is an issue.  They don't like the overhead light on, so we were using little night lights that stay on.  Those cast a light into their bedroom, so I was always getting up to turn the light out for them.  Silly I know.  Well this weekend proved to be a "Winner" for the GizmoMart Lights"  They are able to get to the bathroom, the light comes on when they walk out of the bedroom, lights up the bathroom very well with 6 lights inside.  Then they go back to bed and "30" seconds later the light is out. My Husband mounted it on the side of the cabinet, which is lower but also at their height. so the motion detects them.  Everything is perfect.  They want to stay every weekend now.  Sweet.
I did get this at a discount to give my unbiased opinion.  I would recommend this light to anyone with small children, elderly family member, or just yourself.  No more tripping...

Update:
The handle has stopped reverting to the neutral position, which keeps the water running if you don't pay attention.  I probably lost all the water this thing had saved.  One-star now!

I bought both the One2flush retrofit kit and new dual flush toilets (Toto, American Standard) for our new house.  The difference is big in flushing result.

If you check out the dual flush toilets, the bowls are designed differently with smaller water basin and steeper flow slope.  The retrofit just cut into the released water amount.  The result is ineffective flush.

It's not so easy to install either.  I watched the video on the manufacturer's website and thought it's no big deal, only to realize that the snipped parts take quite a bit of effort afterward.  You may also need to run to a store for other parts if your toilet is old.

We don't use the half flush much now.  I'd recommend saving the money for a replacement toilet.
summary: Weak half flush.  Failing handle wastes water!

The light on the energizer is slightly brighter and diffused than the ray o vac.  The ray o vac light is concentrated into a sort of 8 inch halo.  However, due to it's reliability, have been consistently using the ray o vac on a daily basis for 6 months now and have no complaints thus far.

reviewText: i picked up this impact driver because i wanted a brushless one to go with my brushless hammerdrill and screwgun. it comes to work with me. i work in a cabinet shop and build cabinets and occasinally go out and do some installer work as well. and this little gun here is a compact powerhouse that any type of woodworking or construction professional needs under their belt.  ive drove 1in - 5in wood screws, large panheads into concrete, large confirmats without it breaking a sweat.  i also have used it to undo rusted 15/16 nuts on lawnmower blades (it took a bit of breaking loose but it got it fairly quick). this is a very versatile multi purposeful tool to have in your arsenal for just about any application no matter how big or small. my father has one and he used it to undo the lug nuts on his truck because he left his tire change kit at the house after forgetting to put it back in the truck. the speed control on the bottom is really nice, functional, has it purposes. i use the small 2Ah batteries in it. at work while screwing cabinets together about 30-50 a day with roughly 25 screws  (2in and 1 1/2in  #8) the batteries last all day and part of the next. compared to my none brushed version of this gun it lasts around 3/4 of the day under the same circumstances. overall i love this little gun ive had it for about 2 months now and its still going strong. came with a bit holder and belt clip also.

I just got this installed today, so I haven't had much time to play with it yet. Here are my first impressions. First off, the replacement garage door opener is a big improvement by itself. I like the addition of the motion sensor to automatically turn on the garage door opener lights. I also like the timer delayed closing. We live in the city, so it's nice to know that it's always going to try to close the door after a few minutes if we forget. I also like that it generates and audible / visible alert when it's about to close the garage door (either from the timer or via the gateway). The gateway was pretty easy to install, but I had issues adding our garage door device at first. The gateway connected to the Internet without issue (green light), but I had problems registering the Garage Door as a new device. I power cycled the gateway and then it suddenly worked and successfully registered. The iPhone app isn't spectacular, but it does the job. Anyway, I'm able to open the garage door from my iPhone now which is my reason for purchasing. Only time will tell how reliable this device is and if it keeps on working without hassle. Incidentally, our LiftMaster Internet Gateway is connected to our AT&T modem through a TrendNet gigabit switch without any issues. I think I read a review stating that the gateway needs to be direct connected to your router, but it seems to work behind a switch for me.

I think it's legal in California, although it took some interpretation of the penal code to come to that conclusion. This is not legal advice, ask your own lawyer. But here is the applicable language in the California penal code:

17235.  As used in this part, "switchblade knife" means a knife
having the appearance of a pocketknife and includes a spring-blade
knife, snap-blade knife, gravity knife, or any other similar type
knife, the blade or blades of which are two or more inches in length
and which can be released automatically by a flick of a button,
pressure on the handle, flip of the wrist or other mechanical device,
or is released by the weight of the blade or by any type of
mechanism whatsoever. "Switchblade knife" does not include a knife
that opens with one hand utilizing thumb pressure applied solely to
the blade of the knife or a thumb stud attached to the blade,
provided that the knife has a detent or other mechanism that provides
resistance that must be overcome in opening the blade, or that
biases the blade back toward its closed position.

This is a small lamp, and I find the design attractive. I installed a forty Watt incandescent bulb, though it will support up to sixty Watts, and it seems to be an appropriate output one would expect from such a small lamp - it makes a great table lamp for the entry.

Assembly requires that the cord be manually pulled through the tube on the lamp, which is best done while pushing on the other end at the same time. Before screwing the socket into the top of the lamp, I twisted the cord in the opposite direction to minimize twisting once attached; it feels as though damage to the lamp could result during this process. What the company saves on assembly labor, the customer makes up for in uncertainty during assembly.

The fabric lampshade came out of the package beautifully. Quality fabric stitched nicely, though not necessarily gracefully, with such bulging seams where the ends meet at the outers top and bottom of the shade; but light shines through it with a bright, warm glow. The base came through with only minor cosmetic flaws. There are scratches that I do not notice without effort, and because they're located on the backside on mine, it helps to conceal them.

I enjoy this lamp. I've bought higher quality lamps in the past for less than what this lamp goes for. What I do enjoy is that I get to have an attractive and unobtrusive light source, without the footprint of a typical nightstand-sized bedroom lamp with its shade eating up all the space within the room. Both compact size and beautiful iron scrollwork design are what make this lamp shine.
summary: Compact and Attractive - Assembly Work Required

reviewText:
I did not need to hook up for the inlet water side, it works well with just the flapper valve substitute.

My modification was the overflow tube is almost right against the wall of the tank so the base that slides over the overflow tube wouldn't make it because of the zip lock tie holder. So my dremel tool took care of that and basically  I filed it down flush to the holder. I place a large zip lock around the whole tube and holder. Installed the cam and rubber gasket and it's solid.

The only critical part of the installation is to make sure that the Blue Silicone Dome Gasket is in place, instead of the flapper, and stays in place. The connection to the overflow tube is its only support so getting it tight with cam and the rubber gasket inserted and slid down so it doesn't move up is very important. A leaking bubbly sound will be heard if you do not succeed.

Only one adjustment was the Blue Float quick flush adjustment. It needed to be slid down a bit, which is super easy, just press.

Don't forget there is a minimum height need from the flap base to the top of the tank which is 10". Or the mechanism will be two high to install.

I you just need to install the one part than if something happens and you have kept the flap and handle and chain its just a quick change to put it all back together. It has a 6 year guarantee so its worth a try. I really had no choice with the California drought.

Nice video's on their website. It appears that they do support their customers.  No tools needed, except to get the handle nut off.

I've owned or used a lot of cordless drills, from Black and Decker (ugh), Porter Cable, DeWalt, Milwaulkee, Makita and others, but I'd never heard of the Panasonic until a friend who does a lot of decks introduced me to it. He was using the earlier 12 volt model, but everything I discovered in using that drill applies to this one as well.
Panasonic isn't thought of as a power tool company, but their cordless drills are the best I've ever used, bar none. They've got the fastest recharge rate- 15 minutes- and that translates to more time drilling and less time recharging. It also translates to longer battery life; the less time spent charging, the less the heat buildup, and that's what kills these batteries. I know my friend has been using his on a daily basis for over five years with the original battery. The Panasonic drills also seem to get more useful drilling out of a single charge, something that recent tests by one magazine confirm.
My current 1/2" Makita is still going strong, but if it should happen to give up the ghost, I'm replacing it with a Panasonic.
summary: The Best Kept Secret in Cordless Drills

I too own a Hunter original ceiling fan. I purchased 2 of them around 1980 and was to build a new home in a couple of years so I stored them in my basement until I was ready to install them in my new home.  1987 I was finally able to move into my new home . When I put that home up for sale, I replaced the Hunter fans with other fans and kept these fans for my other new home that I built in 2003. I am sitting here now feeling the nice breeze from the fans as I have installed both of them in my living room which has high ceilings. The low speed is just perfect to create a nice smooth comfortable breeze. Even though these fans are over 30 years old, The blades have never sagged they don't wobble they are simply the best fans ever built in my opinion. I believe if I ever put this house up for sale, I would remove them and take them with me or I would give them to my children for their homes. I just don't think you can find a better fan but you have to find a true original. I don't know about the new reproductions from China. I paid $200 each for them in 1980 on sale. WOW what a bargain. I'm old enough to remember what quality built products were and I clinging to the last bit of quality stuff that I own. You just can't buy stuff like this anymore. I don't think.
summary: They just don't make a better fan in my opinion

I LOVE this wrench. It's the perfect size to carry around in a small pouch that I carry on my belt. I work in a large manufacturing facility and having a small, useful tool kit on my belt is a must. And every tool in it needs to be versatile and accommodate as many situations as possible upon initial response to a repair call. This wrench (and my trusty Knipex (87 01 180 SBA) 7" Cobra Pliers) allow me to take care of about 90% of my calls while out on the floor without having to return to my tool box for more specialized wrenches. It has a large opening for larger bolts/fittings and the jaws are also quite deep. The shorter handle allows tight access and the molded grip is very comfortable to hold. It has markings on both sides (one side is graduated in inches, the other side metric) so if I need a certain socket or a larger wrench the guess work is eliminated when retrieving the correct size. Given their size, it has it's limitations as far as leverage but this is to be expected. They are pretty tough though. If I ever loose or break this wrench, I will promptly buy another to replace it. They have earned their place in my tool belt pouch kit for my always-carried tools around the plant - and I don't give tools a place there unless they are exceptional, functional, and truly worthy.
summary: Perfect size adjustable wrench for tool pouch

reviewText:
I've had this two months and think it's perfect. The Juice was uncomfortably heavy in my pocket, but I hardly notice it on my belt.

The pouch attaches to the belt with a clip, which is great since I leave my belts on my pants, but transfer the Juice to whatever I'm wearing that day - the clip makes this quick and easy. It hasn't ever fallen off (either leather or cloth belts), and the clip is stiff enough I don't think it ever would. It didn't fall off when I was clambering all over things and hanging upside-down at Burning Man.

Update: 6 months in, the leather holding the clip to the knife-pocket tore (fortunately while at work, so it was easy to find the knife laying on the floor).
I took it off my belt every day, which probably caused the wear. But the ease of removability of the clip (vs a loop that requires removing the belt) was the reason I liked this sheath in the first place.

For $7, I'll buy another one and try to be more careful when removing it.

ON THE NEGATIVE SIDE: I've had these for a few months now and, oddly enough I've had 3 of them die! I'm an electrician so I checked the power supply and it was well within specs. I contacted the company and they were very nice in replacing the units at no charge. However, I think I may buy a few more as "spares" for the future, when these may not be available any more. When a halogen bulb dies, it's easy, quick, and cheap to replace. But when one of THESE dies, you need to replace the whole lamp.
Also, these are definitely not what I'd call "warm white". Compared to the halogens they are noticeably more blue/green. I'd say about 3500-4000k temperature. My wife says we can live with it, but I've ordered some Tamiya Acrylic X-26 Clear Orange paint which I've heard could be used to tint the LEDs to a warmer color. I'll update this review if/when I get around to that.

This is great accelerator and works with all my CA/Super Glues. This one works a little different than other accelerators I have used in the past that is worth mentioning since the description doesn't state anything. I am used to accelerators that work pretty much on contact. This one does not work like that. After spraying, it does take a few seconds for it to start drying the glue; about 5 seconds or so. It also takes up to about 15-20 seconds for the glue to be completely dried and hardened.  The instructions do mention this.  However, with that being said, this one dries much more clear than the fast acting accelerators. I believe it is worth the trade off. Some of the faster acting ones actually dry "cloudy" or "whitish". This one does not do that, it dries very clear on all applications I have used it for. I have used it to fill gaps, some pretty significant for pens. Use it for crack filling, and CA finish for wood pens. Works great for all I need it for. Unlike the awful Gunvault GV2000S, this safe is trustworthy.  Always opens on first or second try.  Has a dedicated battery compartment that is highly visible and easy to use (unlike the Gunvault).  Does not seem to permit "paper clip" opening of the manual lock (see videos of other brands whose manual locks are readily defeated with a paperclip).  Door is held secure by two very thick (~1") motorized bolts, again far superior to the other brands that use dinky little clips.

The only thing I don't like about this safe is that it has no door handle.  Once you see the green lights and hear the bolts retract, you need to find an easy way to grab the door.  I usually grab the circular fingerprint assembly.

Bear in mind, this is a small safe.  Good for one large or two small guns.  If you need more, buy its larger cousin.

Barska safes cost more, but after owning a few others, I wouldn't settle for less.  Its worth a few extra bucks.

Overall, a very good product. But the rechargeable batteries that come with this is very anemic. After buying this at Costco, I was disappointed when I found that the included batteries were only 900mAh. Nevertheless, I wanted to give it a try. Set up was a breeze. Unscrew the battery door, insert the battery, re-screw the door and ready. My purpose for these lights is to light up my driveway. But I chose not to screw the lights into my driveway. I didn't want to commit myself to a certain location for the lights (since I'm prone to changing my mind). Also, I figured I would have to periodically replace the rechargeable batteries and the repeated unscrewing of the screws in my concrete pavers would cause stripping of the screw holes over time. So, I decided to have them simply resting on the ground (not screwed into the ground).

Now comes my major issue with the Manor House Solar LED Marker Lights: the 900mAh batteries. In my first week of use, the lights would come on at dusk and then turn off after only a few hours. At first I thought maybe the lights didn't have enough sunlight to charge the batteries. But after a week of exposure to sunny days here in Los Angeles, I continued to have only about 3-5 hours of light coming from these LED lights. I thought about returning them to Costco. But then I remembered I have some 2000mAh rechargeable batteries lying around. With the 2000mAh batteries installed, these LED lights stay on ALL night. Yes, from dusk to dawn the LED lights are lighting up my driveway. Again, the difference is that I replaced the 900mAh batteries that it came with, with 2000mAh batteries of my own. FYI: I used Eneloop 2000mAh size AA batteries (purchased on Amazon, about $16 for a set of four), one each for each light. This is the reason for the one star deduction. Otherwise, these are great lights, feel very rugged and so far water resistant. I've had it exposed to rain, and water from the sprinkler system and so far no issues. I would definitely buy this again. Hopefully, the price will drop since I anticipate having to buy more 2000mAh batteries for the lights. Which is an added expense.

As a side note, please keep in mind that these lights need exposure to direct sunlight for several hours a day in order to more fully charge the batteries (ie. in order to have the lights on ALL night long). If you place these lights in a location that gets only a few hours of sunlight a day, then you may notice the lights lasting a limited time at night. Roughly, I found that for every hour of direct sunlight exposure it gets, is the same number hours it will be lit up at night. So if you place the lights in a location that gets around 3 hours of direct sunlight, then the lights will be lit for only about 3 hours at night. This is a rough approximation, of course. So place the lights appropriately.
summary: I switched the batteries to 2000mAh batteries and now the lights stay on all night!
