The first point I would note considering would be the pricing, because these are currently sitting at an elevated pricing point. I would encourage some comparison for what you want before picking them up. Having said that, the bulb itself is actually a good bulb, and it is one that has been doing well within my home. I have been testing it for well over a month to check durability, and it is still going strong. Mind you, this is early in its lifespan and will have to be updated if something transpires, but it is doing well so far.

So, why LED? If you are someone that was like I was a few years prior and asks that, consider a few points. First, there is pricing related to consumption and replacement. If you look up charting on how long LED lasts, you can see that LED significantly outlasts filament bulbs. Not only that, they also provide stability and a much lower consumption rate, so they save on energy over time. As far as lighting goes, you have a much cleaner light, so it is not like looking through film. That means a lot when you want to see outside of the blurry haze many inferior types provide. They also do not get that hot, so safety via placement and touch is much better. This concerns me as a home owner and as a parent.

Additionally, this is a dimmable, and it works well. You combine those elements and you are talking about being able to replace a 60 watt bulb in most cases.

I haven't received this saw yet, but it's pretty much the same as the old one I am replacing. The old one was purchased at an estate sale for 100 bucks. I was only able to cut six (6) 3-inch aluminum discs before the Tiwanese motor decided to burn up and quit working. It was built in 1983, so no telling how many hours are on it. (I wish I had that 100 bucks back now!). I went to WW Graingers to get a new motor, expecting about $125 for a replacement. Well, electric motors have taken a flying leap in cost as the replacement motor was a whopping $275!!  I could not in all conscience put such an expensive motor on such an old and worthless bandsaw. So I decided to put that $275 towards this little Shop Fox, partly because it had a 3/4HP motor vs. the 1/2HP of all the rest. (I really wanted the next model up with the nicer stand and even the ones with coolant flow). But for as little as I need to cut stock, this should do fine for a very long time...let's hope.

In regards to the stand, let's face it, all of them at this price level are pretty cruddy and flimsy, and I fully expect to build a better rolling frame out of 1" square steel tubing (and have the saw a bit higher too). I had purchased a couple of the Olsen saw blades for my old unit, and they worked pretty well, at least up until the motor died. I don't expect to be cutting much steel anyway. (I also invested in a set of new guide bearings for the old saw, but their quality wasn't that great). One important thing to pass along is the set up of the blade in the guide bearings. You absolutely MUST have at least a .001 clearance between the bearings for the blade, and the only way to get accurrate with this is with feeler guages before you install the blade. On my first attempt at this, I did not have this clearance and the saw didn't run very well. (DUH!). Also, remember that the thickness of the blades vary with each manufacturer, so if you remove the blade that comes stock with this unit and replace it with an Olsen, be sure to put a micrometer or caliper on the old and the new and make any adjustments. At the very least, simply make sure the new blade passes easily between the guide bearings.

One other very important point when ordering this saw is to check your "basket" before submitting to pay. If you are being charged shipping charges...and in the case of this saw....over $100, then don't do it. If you buy "straight" from Amazon, they will charge shipping. But if you do a bit of hunting, you will find other companies that will ship this for free....even under the Amazon banner! (I am not a member of their "Super Saver" program, which I assume allows free shipping). So, important that you check this before committing to the purchase.

I would not be concerned about the "negative" response from the guy with the old Sears unit. You won't need "special" blades. But for sure, the ones that come on the new Shop Fox won't be very good. A couple of the $10 Olsen "Hardbacks" will be a good investment.

In the "for what its worth" department, my "old" bandsaw that just burned up was cutting through the 3" aluminum just fine, and amazingly, (at least to me), there was only a .007 (seven thousandths) difference between where it started to cut and the bottom of the cut. That's pretty good to me!! In regards to blade tension, I simply hand-tightened the adjustment wheel as tight as I could manually do it....don't put a set of Channel locks on the wheel to get it any tighter. It is also good practice to vacuum out the inside where the wheels are as you don't want those metal flakes coming between the blade and the bearings. Just take care of it and it should take care of you. Perhaps if things get better economically, I can get one of these with the swivel head and coolant system. I run a little prototype shop out of my garage so I don't have a lot of room for big stuff.

I would also like to get one of the ShopFox Vertical Milling machines with the feed servo. The Bridgeports are simply too big for me. Growing up, my Dad had one of those nice Rockwell vertical mills, which again, are the perfect size. But its getting very hard to find those units in good condition, and, you can't buy parts (that's the main thing for me). If I ever need something large made, then I'll leave that for my friends at the CNC machine shop. I already have a nice-enough lathe...a vintage South Bend Type A, and a cool Atlas metal shaper.
I made a couple of very nice and VERY professional high-definition short videos that you should watch sometime. The lathe video is on Vimeo, and the Atlas Shaper is on YouTube. I'll include some links here, but Amazon usually doesn't allow them (I don't think).
[...]

[...]

So anyway, that's my input....let the chips fly!!
summary: Replacement For Very Old H. Bandsaw

First of all, I have always used MK tile saws, but I was visiting family when a tile project was suggested. I didn't have my tools and needed a wet saw versus a score'n'snap tile cutter. I didn't want to spend big bucks on another saw. I purchased this saw from one of the local DIY stores for under $100 and hoped it would last through the project. I was able to complete a bathroom, kitchen, and hallway project with very few issues...almost 300 sq/ft!

After opening the box, I was a little disappointed because the saw is probably 90% plastic construction and the metal top seemed a little too thin to last. I was surprised at how well everything worked.

Would definitely recommend this saw for the home DIY'er who wants pro-quality results.

PROS:
- price
- ease of assembly
- easy to use
- adequate for small tiles through larger tiles up to 18"
- small footprint (doesn't take up much space)
- table top has easy to read graduated measurement guide
- included blade works well

CONS:
- small table size will limit effective tile cutting for tiles over 18". Its possble to do larger tiles, but larger saws would be better suited.
- water well is difficult to clean out once finished with the project. Slots in the table top allow excess water and tile debris to drain back into reservoir, resulting in a sloppy sludge flurry.
- water well/reservoir is difficult to fill with a standard size cup or container. I had to use a small, long neck plant waterer
- water reservoir is small and requires constant refilling. Not a big deal if you keep an eye on the water levels though.
- cord storage bar is way too small for effective power chord storage
- many of the pieces seem to thin to hold up to extended use (even though I had no problems through 3 projects)

LED lights in this configuration, made in the shape of a standard incandescent light bulb, have one inherent drawback  light is not projected out of the bottom hemisphere of the bulb.  Thus, while incandescent and CFL bulbs disburse light evenly throughout the surrounding space, these LED bulbs project most of their light through the top half or the half opposite from the screw in base.  Thus, I have found that this type of LED bulb is not as versatile as incandescent and CFL bulbs and that there are more limited locations where these LED bulbs will work well.

I am using these two LED bulbs facing down in a bedside lamp that is covered by an opaque lamp shade.  They work great in this lamp  the light is a pleasant color approximating that of an incandescent bulb and the light is bright enough for comfortable reading in bed.  I should note that the light output of some old 60 watt incandescent bulbs in my home is 870 lumens, while the stated light output from these LED bulbs is almost 10% less at 800 lumens.  These LED bulbs, however, use only 9.5 watts of power.  They are economical and should last a long time.  Just be aware that they may not work as well as incandescent bulbs in every location.
summary: Works Great in the Right Location

reviewText: haven't used it yet, but looks well made

And here's why...

I vacuumed some liquid with this filter and it turned to mush (not really, but it got wet and nasty and had to be tossed out).
The HEPA filter can handle liquids.

This filter is disposable, and they tend to clog quick in my experience.
The HEPA filter is washable and reusable.

The HEPA filter will, as a bonus, also filter 99.97% of all nastiness down to .03 microns.

The HEPA costs more up front, but it will work longer and serve you better while it does.

All that aside, this filter is satisfactory IF you are working in a DRY environment. Works just fine for that. It does not like wet, and that's what shop-vacs are for (imo)

Our home uses security floodlights to light up the backyard and driveway. The floods do a good job, but they are difficult (read dangerous) to change. That's because changing them requires leaning way over the railing of our deck. Given this the less often we need to change the floodlights the better. This is problematic with the old style incandescent bulbs (or even the new CFLs) because their lifetime hours are so limited.

This LED flood (BR40 DIMMABLE 15 Watt (72W) E26, Warm White by Muller Licht) claims an "extra long lifetime of 30,000 hours of use." Under "normal" operation this means that I will only need to change the flood every 27 years. German engineering at its best!

However, as I have mentioned in other LED bulb reviews, the lifetime rating of an LED bulb can be misleading. What is usually rated is the lifetime of the LED element itself. What is not rated is the lifetime of the internal electronics required to drive the LEDs. These can, and do, fail much earlier--sometimes within days of installing the LED lamp. So keep this in mind when you see an LED rating like 30,000 hours of use.

Still, for energy efficiency that it will realize and the chance that the bulb lamp will somewhat approach the rated life, using the LED Light Bulb BR40 DIMMABLE 15 Watt (72W) E26, Warm White by Muller Licht is well worth it!
summary: A Better Solution for Difficult to Change Floodlamps

reviewText:
We bought a significant quantity of this tape for a major painting project in our home.  We used it to protect woodwork - crown molding, baseboards, chair rails, etc..  Then we ran out and ended up using the "blue stuff".  When we were finished and removed the tape, we found very little, if any, difference between the two.  The green stuff - Frog tape - was almost twice the cost.
Now - we did NOT use it for taping directly on sheetrock to divide painting colors on the wall.  The "bleed' factor was no better with the green than with the blue in our use of it.  Perhaps the green would perform better than the blue when applied directly on sheetrock. ???
Bottom line:  for the cost, stick with the name brand "blue stuff" and find the best buy that you can - and buy plenty!

I purchased this floor box for use in my family room where we have need for a power, HDMI and ethernet in the floor.  I purchased the model with the brushed nickel finish to match the other hardware in the room because the box is in plain sight.  Unfortunately, the cover is the biggest problem.  The loosely assembled device was wrapped in plastic and then put into a tight fitting box.  No additional protection for the cover's finish!  So the sandwich of cardboard to plastic against the cover resulted in random polishing while the unit was shipped place-to-place.  So my brushed nickel finish has "bright" spots on it.  Makes it a real eyesore installed against the dark floor.

PROS:
- it's heavy duty, divided, so it makes the code official happy.
- the construction of the cover is solid and the port doors fit well.
- good gasketing provided.
- roomy so it's easy to tuck in the wiring.

CONS:
- insufficient packaging leaves the finish blemished.
- knockouts are all the same size, which does not allow for use of a pre-terminated cables like an HDMI, without modification (had to enlarge with a step taper bit). It needs at least one concentric knockout on the datacomm side to be more installation friendly.
- no response from customer service.

In all, it's probably the cheapest in-floor package out there and will do the job with some modification if you have to use pre-terminated cables (HDMI is about the largest you can deal with in this box and through a duplex keystone.  The packaging is just poor.  The norm would have been to have the cover finish protected with peel-off film like other brands I've installed.  Lesson learned on saving a few bucks over buying a Hubbel unit.  Seems my only option will be to see if the metal polishing company a few towns over can "re-grain" the finish evenly so that it doesn't look so bad since Top Greener does not respond to a customer's concerns.  That surprised me because the company was quick to email to see if I was satisfied, and I responded with my issue via that email as instructed.  I received no reply and a few weeks later received the same email inquiry!  Guess it's just automated.  After that, I tried calling customer service via the toll-free number and nada.

I've purchased hundred of items from Amazon and Amazon Marketplace affiliates.  The few prior occasions where I had problems with products received, a remedy was practically effortless with a quick email or phone call.  Unfortunately, not this time.  Therefore, I am providing my honest feelings and detail of my problem, including photos taken when fresh out of the packaging upon delivery.
summary: Do yourself the favor and purchase something like this at a local brick & mortar electrical supply.

reviewText:
I've needed to upgrade my doweling jig for years.  Previous to this I was using a very simple Bench Dog jig that worked perfectly, but was limited to drilling only two holes before re-positioning and only at a 3/8" offset from the surface of a board (ideal for typical 3/4" stock).  I purchased the JessEm jig to allow for different offsets for working in different thickness materials.  Unlike a self-centering jig the JessEm allows you to adjust the offset rather than be restricted to centering only.

The quality of the jig is excellent, which I expected considering the price.  I've used jigs that bend and wobble when working with denser woods, but that is never a problem with this one.  It's heavy and thick, and I can't imagine the kind of force it would take to break or bend it.  The included 3/8" drill bit seems to be a rather soft steel; it started very sharp but didn't stay that way for long... but I'm not bothered by that.  Anyone looking at this expensive of a doweling jig probably has many good bits already.  Overall I feel the JessEm is a little overpriced, but it's a small price to pay to not be cursing while I work.

All in all, i am very satisified. I can't wait to build something else and use this!

reviewText:
Honestly, my main complaint with these is just their price.  They seem to work fairly well.  The temperature sensors may be a little too sensitive (I see one that's only relatively near to a vent go down too fast when the AC is running so the system shuts off too soon until I can move it) but otherwise they work.  They seem to be fairly good at detecting when I'm here or not too.  Overall I have no complaints about their actual functionality.  But the price is a different story...

If these were $20 or something it would be no big deal.  If they were $30 I'd be a bit upset, but still wouldn't knock off a star.  At their current price ($79 at the time of this review) it is a serious consideration of whether to invest in them or not and I MUST knock off points because the price is just too extreme to not be a serious consideration in whether or not even to buy the product.  First of all, hardware-wise, these are roughly equivalent to a really simple Arduino or Raspberry Pi style device with a temperature sensor and I guess it uses some simple infrared sensor for the home/away detection.  For approximately one third to one fourth of the price someone with the actual know-how to build such things could easily create their own sensor that either directly controls the system or maybe even could just emulate these and connect to the actual sensor control.  Unfortunately, most of us lack that know-how.  And they're counting on it and taking advantage.  To my mind that is a bit dirty and the practice itself is worth knocking off more points in the rating.  What's more, they don't even sell a cheaper single pack for those of us who don't really technically need two.  You have to buy two even if you only need one.  (Well, I just went ahead and put both in the same room at different points to measure more accurately how the air actually flows, but I really only needed one in the end.)  So all in all, between the rather exceptional price and the choice behind doing so despite the fact that the hardware can't cost them even a fraction of this I have to take off two stars because this is just ridiculous frankly.

If you lack the know-how to build your own then you'll pretty much have to buy these.  At least they work without any real caveats.
summary: They work fine.  But good god that price!

These are absolutely the best performing solar lights Ive ever owned. They have the best and easiest method of installation. The light housing separates from the bracket that holds it making the installation of the bracket so easy. Once you have the bracket mounted where you want it just slide the housing back onto it. Simple and if you want to just pop it off to use as a temporary mobile light source you can. When done just pop it back on the bracket. The 25 LEDs put out a nice amount of light. There are options on how you want them to work. Mine are set for low light at night and when they detect motion they switch to bright for 30 seconds before going back to dim. But even on dim they put out a nice amount of light. When I bought my very first one they were rated for 500 cycles meaning the batteries would continue to recharge for about a year and a half. My first light went out at 2 years and my second at 2 1/2 years. The other 11 have now surpassed 3 1/2 years and still shining brightly. Im about on the 32nd parallel and have long summer days and about 9+ hour days in winter. All of my lights shine brightly throughout the night. This Qualtech Screw Extractor Set, #1-5 Sizes from Drill America is a super handy, compact set that is designed to remove stripped or broken screws.

These are made of heat treated carbon steel so they are tough and should last forever with appropriate care. I keep my carbon steel tools lightly oiled to prevent rust and they are pretty much indestructible. The 5 extractors come in a small, plastic pouch so they will always be together, ready for use.

If you've never used a screw extractor before, it's a fairly simple process. There are plenty of YouTube videos that demonstrate the process very clearly.

This particular set is designed for use with a drill. There are others that have a hole in the top so you can use them manually but this set does not. You will also need a center punch, some safety goggles, some thread cutting oil, an appropriate sized drill bit and some penetrating oil if the screw you are extracting is rusted. All of these items (except the drill) are quite inexpensive and you can use for other tasks.

If you do any kind of home repair or DIY, you need a screw extractor set and this is a good one.
summary: If you do any kind of home repair or DIY, you need a screw extractor set

RoomMates JL1369M Star Wars EP VII Prepasted Surestrip Mural, 10.5' W x 6' H is amazing to look at when put on the wall. This is no small item. It is 10 foot by 6 foot wall covering. The colors and details are sharp and crisp. It does however require a second person to apply it. It is not difficult to put on the wall but there are things that do need to be done.

First, treat this as wallpaper, not a decal or poster. Prime the wall space with wallpaper prime paint. Then get the pieces layed out in the order that they will go up in. Use a level when placing the very first panel. You want it to be perfectly straight as all the other panels will follow the first and if you are off at the beginning you will have a crooked image. It is simple to do, just remember to take the time for this. Do not try to rush it. This requires some patience and focus, but once you are started it goes on quickly and the results are awesome.

RoomMates JL1369M Star Wars EP VII Prepasted Surestrip Mural is going to make a boring room look fantastic. Highly recommended.

reviewText: As described.

I refer to the following products below: Watts Premier 501026 Zero Waste Reverse Osmosis Retrofit Kit Watts Premier 560043 Water Filtration Booster Pump Kit Bought this unit from Amazon Warehouse deals at around $150, so we're already starting out ahead. We've had Sparklett's service for years, and since we bought a house, I've been chomping at the bit to install an RO unit. But there's another problem. We live in Southern California, and as such, water is both a precious resource, and we're also inherently conscious of waste in general. The problem with the majority of RO units, is that for each unit of water you get out, you're dumping another 4 units down the drain. So imagine every glass of water you drink - before you drink it, take 4 other glasses of water and pour them down the drain. This was a deal-breaker for me, and I'd have rather stuck with using Sparklett's (though, you trade-off things like carbon footprint of the truck driving around and dropping off bottles at our doorstep). Thankfully, there's the Zero Waste kit offered by Watts, which takes what would otherwise be waste water, and sends it back to the hot water side of your plumbing (using a high-pressure pump to do the work). The downside, is that this kit costs nearly $200. Amortized over a year, the whole deal is about the same price as we'd be paying for water delivery, so it's still worth it if you can get over the large one-time cash outlay. To save a bit of money, I took a chance, and bought the RO Booster kit, which includes the same pressure switch and the pump. Subsequently, I called up Watts, and ordered the solenoid (~$35), and the extra Adapta-Valve ($8), along with some extra tubing ($8). In the end, the whole cost of doing it piecemeal like this helped me save around $50. The added benefit of getting the Zero Waste Kit (ZWK), is that you actually have to do less work in total installation. You don't have to use the waste water return lines on the faucet (since the "waste water" goes back into your pipes), and you don't have to drill the saddle tube into your sink pipes. This was a big plus since overall, these seem like short-comings of the system in general. Installation-wise, this unit is fairly straight-forward if you're handy with a wrench - it's more just the contortioning that you're going to be doing under your sink to get to all of the fittings. If you've got a good amount of room and a fairly new house, you'll be in good shape. The quick-connect Watts joints are a God-send, having to use compression fittings is a hassle otherwise. I wish that *all* of the connectors in the kit were quick-connect, but sadly I can understand that they'd want to save money with compression fittings where they don't need to be disconnected with any regularity. The only downside with the kit, if you're not going to go the route of the Zero-waste kit, is the saddle valve. In my opinion, it's a poor way to tap into the downstream pipe for waste water. Ideally you'd just get a T for the pipe, and go from there, but obviously Watts couldn't account for all configurations of plumbing, so it's the best alternative.
summary: Adios Sparkletts.  Get the Zero Waste Kit in addition to this!

reviewerName: Trust me, I'm not a hipster
reviewText:
This flashlight is not very good. It is bright and has good throw distance, but other than that it doesn't have much going for it. The beam pattern is very poor; the hot spot is pretty tight which gives good distance, but the spill is very very wide and too dim to be useful. There are numerous rings in the beam pattern of various brightnesses and it is not smooth at all. The balance of the light makes it not very comfortable to hold. There is a button that indicates the battery level by displaying blue, yellow, or red; while better than nothing it's not all that useful especially since it's hidden behind the protective shroud. The construction of the light itself is decent and I have no concerns of it breaking or being unreliable.

The worst part about this light is that the battery is proprietary (two 18650 batteries sealed together with three contacts on the top and one on the bottom) so it can only be charged by the flashlight and not by a charger. I initially thought the light would charge the two battery cells independently which would be a good thing, however the battery will charge with the tail cap turned off. The center terminal is the positive for cell 1, the second (middle) terminal is negative for cell 1 an positive for cell 2, the third (outer) terminal is the negative for cell 2. This setup makes it impossible to independently charge the cells which leads to voltage differentials that reduces the lifespan of them. A voltmeter confirmed that the cells do not charge to the same voltage level. Not only must you charge the proprietary battery in the flashlight but you must use a special double-male USB cable; this means if you lose, damage, or simply forget to bring the special cable with you then you're out of luck with charging the supplied battery. Fortunately the flashlight will work with two standard 18650 cells, however I do not recommend using the flashlight to charge any battery other than the supplied one.

For this price level you would hope to have more features and better usability. There are only two brightness levels, and you must cycle through the SOS mode to get from the low to high settings. Since the beam pattern has a tight hot spot and very little spill this light is really only suitable for long distance and won't be that great to use around the campsite or indoors; the low setting is too low to be helpful since the beam pattern doesn't work well at close range. The protective shroud that covers the USB port and battery level indicator button is time consuming and obnoxious; but is necessary to use to maintain water resistance. Charging initiates automatically when you plug in the supplied USB cable to charge the flashlight, so it's strange that you must press the battery level button to initiate charging for an external device; if you plug in your phone and forget to press the button you might wake up to a dead phone on your camping trip.

Pros:
Bright
Good throw distance
Can charge external electronics
High quality LED

Cons:
Poor beam pattern
Must use special USB cable to charge battery
Supplied proprietary battery is useless except in this flashlight
Must cycle through SOS mode to get back to brightest level
Poor design and lack of features for the price
Uncomfortable balance
It takes half a second for the light to come on after pressing the power button
Expensive for what you get
Low level too low
Must press the battery level button to initiate external charging

Conclusion:
While not horrible, this flashlight is nothing special at all, for the price I would certainly avoid it, and I would definitely not recommend this light to anyone. For the same price you can get much better flashlights, for example the P25 from Nitecore which uses the same Cree XM-L2 LED, also has a built in charger, is much smaller, is almost as bright, has 5 brightness levels, SOS, strobe, and beacon modes, and a great beam pattern, belt clip, lanyard, belt pouch, extra O-rings, I could go on...
summary: Decent if it's a gift, bad for the price

Robust knife with the safety features that are ideal for a glove compartment/console knife. The blade includes a serrated edge, a seat belt slitter and a pointed hammer point designed to break windows. This is a product that would be a great emergency asset in every vehicle.

I was able to get some good use out of this, but probably more of a 3.5 star blade.  I used the blade for a few projects here and there, cutting between .120 and .250 wall steel tube.  Did a good job, in my opinion.  I ran it on a Harbor Freight miter saw using a HF speed controller to bring down the blade speed (but at the expense of some torque on the motor).  Only recently did it really struggle on some .120, but notably it's been running as a 49-tooth blade for quite a while without much fuss (the tooth damage was my fault due to insufficient piece clamping).  I may try to sharpen it and see if it's still usable, but the latest round of cutting really dulled it out.  I bought it from a local box store some time ago, and I don't recall it being any cheaper than what it's selling for here today.  The docking of stars is primarily for the cost of the blade and some dulling teeth factor (not sure the level at which this is expected or acceptable), but otherwise I felt it was a good purchase.
summary: I was able to get some good use out of this

This unit was purchased to replace a previous unit that had melted on my furnace causing the mounting case sides to implode. This is the fourth replacement. The first one shorted out the motor when the internal water supply tubing came loose from it's mounting and got caught in the fan blade and shorted out the fan motor. The second one simply melted and constricted the fan blade and shorted out the motor again. The third one was mounted in the same spot but this time rather than having a hot water supply line to the unit, I changed it to a cold water line hoping it would help cool the unit. No luck again. This fourth replacement is now placed higher up on the furnace hoping that would help but I am extremely doubtful. So much so that I am presently exploring having an external steam producing unit with a probe attached to the furnace expelling steam as needed. The beauty of that unit would not only be no drain line to contend with but also being mostly external which would allow repair work to be completed without having to turn off the furnace. I personally think Honeywell should have created a much more heat resistant housing than they have. I will never buy one again and I wish you well if you do.
summary: I changed it to a cold water line hoping it would help cool the unit

I think it's hard to go wrong with a Freud blade.  I use this on a Ridgid R4512 table saw.  Great quality and clean cuts every time.

My chief complaint is that the chart they include that tells you which blades/spacers/chippers to use to get a certain width was not accurate.  I made test cuts according to their chart and measured with my calipers and the width was not accurate.  So I suggest building your own guide.  Just take a scrap piece of wood and use the different blades/spacers/chippers until you get the desired width.  Then record the configuration right on the wood next to the cut.

It's a lot of extra work to set up your own chart, but it's a necessity if you want to get accurate cuts.  For the price of these blades and the reputation of Freud, this is almost inexcusable.  Hopefully they'll get this fixed soon.
summary: Great except for one rather large nuisance

reviewText:
First, the physical: The unit is big, so it takes the entire area of the electrical box. If you have a lot of wires in there -- and I did -- then it is quite a chore getting everything to fit. That made it difficult to install.
Second, the programming: Programming is not easy. It should be, because it has a lot of buttons to push (you only see 2 in the picture because the others are behind a flip down cover), but in reality it was more difficult to program than my old Honeywell Programmable Timer with fewer buttons. It is also difficult to read what you are programming because the screen isn't very bright.
Third: the electrical. It requires a 3 wire connection (there are four wires on the unit but the red isn't used for a typical installation), so you must have a neutral wire to make it work. Not a big deal, but not every electric box has that easily accessible.
Fourth: the batteries. Supposedly they wear out and must be replaced at some point. That's a pain. My Honeywell has a permanent memory so it doesn't have replaceable batteries, which makes it better in my book.
Fifth: the look. It isn't very pretty. The gray buttons aren't that attractive and make it look clunky compared to the Honeywell timer, which has sleek white buttons which are much more attractive.
summary: Okay if you need an inexpensive timer

reviewText: I have been making fun of my mom for the last few years because she is always buying solar light strings, and solar garden statues, solar, solar, solar.  So one evening I was over at my parents house after the sun went down and I saw all the lights she had in the backyard light up!  WOW, it was so beautiful!  It was at that moment that I decided I wanted to get solar lights for my backyard!  I found these and was so excited that I ordered them right away.  Initially I was attracted to the flowers on and then I also liked the various colors of the lights.  When the lights arrived I liked the fact the lights have a solar pack and on that pack was a button that powered the flowers.  I pushed the button and all the lights came on and I pushed it again and the lights blinked.  I just fell in love with them!  I strung the lights through my jasmine bush next to the front wall and made sure the solar pad was attached to the wall and visible.  In the evening it was so nice to be able to walk by my jasmine bush and to see the pretty little lights twinkling in the evening breeze.  I am totally changed and can't wait to get another set of solar lights so I can make my yard a sparkling paradise.  Disclaimer: This product was supplied to me at a discount or free by the manufacturer or seller to test and evaluate and give an unbiased and honest review which I give in my own words from my personal experience with the use, functionality and testing of this product and is in no way influenced by the manner of which I received it.
summary: Beautiful sparking lights with a variety of colors.  I love the look of them.

reviewText:
In the past six months we did a remodel of our bathroom located in our walkout basement. Because we were apprehensive about mold and mildew, we opted for a Panasonic Whisper Ceiling fan which ended up being a good choice.
When the opportunity came to try out this module on our fan, I was both intrigued as well as apprehensive. This 'nightlight' is designed to sense the relative humidity and temperaturein and calculate a dew point. The fan is activated through the sensor based on the dew point and will turn the fan off automatically when the fan is no longer needed. This reminds me of my Prius which works in a similar way with battery and gas usage going through a computer.
Straight out of the mailbox, my husband and I scurried down to the bathroom figuring this would be at best a half hour job. No way. We removed the plastic fan cover, snapped in the sensor, and positioned the nightlight. Then we just replaced the fan cover.
This seems to be working as promised. Since we are continually monitoring our power consumption and are more than a little forgetful about turning things off, this is a nice add-on.
summary: Great Instructions, Easy Installation, and It Works Without Issues

reviewText:
I've had this gun for a little over a year and it is a dog.  It worked great the first time out but it has malfunctioned in some capacity ever since then.  I've shot less than 300 nails with the gun and the first problem I noticed was the exaust leak.  Since the second time I used the tool, it has had an exaust leak.  I've broken the gun down, checked all of the seals, cleaned everything and the problem temporarily goes away but it always comes back.  The more recent problem I've had is the gun stops firing.  I have not figured it out but it seems the air releases but the hammer does not.  When it happens, I'll repeatedly bump a scrap piece of lumber until it starts nailing again.

I've maintained the gun well ... oiled it as instructed and really like the weight, balance and the belt hook.  It just does not function consistently.  I've since ordered a Senco FP41xp and I'm hoping it performs much better.

reviewText:
Great clamps! Sure gives you better placement options and versatility on light stands and trusses with the drilled mounting holes. You can better fill in or evenly distribute fixtures. If you have smaller fixtures, these clamps allow you to space them closer together than the mounting holes in your truss or T-bars allow so you can fit more on, or if you have larger fixtures that you need to space further apart you can space them out as desired.
Another great thing about these is that you can replace the bolt with a longer one, if needed for other purposes. This is great for me as I sometimes use a whole truss system and other times I just use the stands with T-bars and side arms. Putting in a longer bolt allows me to bolt 2 of these clamps to the tops of each T-bar so I can keep fixtures on the T-bars for use on stands or I can clamp the T-bars to the truss without having to unmount and remount each individual fixture. A real time saver!
summary: Versitile and quality clamps. Well worth the investment!

It's inexpensive and it mostly does what it's supposed to do but the battery life claim is nonsense. I've had this installed for 5 months and have already replaced the batteries twice. What's more troubling is that when this device is used with the standard SmartThings device handler, you cannot use the app or WebCoRE to see the battery level and have to go to the setup menu on the thermostat to see how much battery life is left. And when the batteries die, the thermostat simply stops working. Which could be a disaster if you are on vacation or this is used in a second home. They should have included a low battery mode that will set a base temperature and sound an audible alert when the batteries are almost dead. I wish I had spent more money and purchased a more sophisticated z-wave thermostat.

At first I was overwhelmed by all the pieces, but once you get the hang of it, the assembly was smooth sailing.  I recommend connecting the small keychain rings of the crystal pendants to the bottom plate prior to connecting it to the rest of the fixture (per my wife's suggestion).  It's tedious but once you find an efficient strategy, it gets easier and faster.

Some problems I ran into:

1.  The machine screws that came in the box were too long.  I ended up using 1.25" screws instead of the included 1.5" screws.  If you run into this problem, you can either use shorter screws or use standard 8-32 nuts instead of the cap nuts that come in the box.  The nuts will not be visible so I don't know why cap nuts are even included.

2.  The 1.5" machine screws included in the box seemed to be a non-standard thread as the standard 8-32 nuts I had didn't smoothly fit in them.  This resulted in some stripped threads but I used different screws anyway so it wasn't a big deal.

3.  The instructions are nearly useless.

4.  The bulbs are partially visible which may be harsh on the eyes.

5.  The plastic wrap (used for protection) that surrounds the upper band of pendants can be difficult to take off completely since some of it is sandwiched between metal parts.

Even with these problems, the fixture is very nice so I rate it between a 3.5 and 4.
summary: Beautiful fixture with some flaws and annoyances

reviewText:
This 3/4 hp unit is the best choice. Plenty of power, big enough but not too big, very good quality, not too loud and simple to install. Only problem I had was one of the gaskets rode up on me a bit and it took a few minutes and several mounting tries to figure out something was wrong. When something breaks around the house, or I need a part replaced on my car, I like to do it myself. I also like to tinker with my car and add performance parts and things like that. I needed a set of tools with deep and shallow sockets, and I needed a case to go with it. I got this set for a steal from my local WalMart, and I'm pretty satisfied. It doesn't have every tool under the sun but it is a great full featured set of sockets.

As far as the warranty, its great to have, but its not like craftsman where you can go to sears and get it replaced. That would be great, but I don't live by a sears, as they seem to be vanishing into thin air, so even if I bought craftsman I couldn't just go out and pick the part up anyways.

The sockets are well organized, and the gold labels make them really easy to identify. You've got a full set if 1/4 and 3/8 sockets, and you've got shallow and deep sockets in both sizes. You also get a set of wrenches, not too many sizes but they can be useful. The ratchets themselves seem very sturdy, along with the sockets. The 1/4 ratchet is great for times when you're limited on space or have a part that shouldn't be torqued too much.

I've got one thing I don't like, I would've liked BOTH sides of the case to have a snug fit on the sockets. The case is meant to be opened logo up, if you open it the other way the sockets will fall out.

Overall, if you need a sort of "mechanics" set of sockets and ratchets, this is a great set.
summary: Nice tool set for the casual mechanic and do-it-yourself-er.

Update 1-5-16
It has been brought to my attention that the box I received may not be the same as the box you receive. I did receive 25, 130 volt bulbs as I said in my review. This may have been an exception so don't count on getting the same kind of box that was shipped to me. For the record I am on my second bulb out of the box; the bulbs go into an application that burns continuously and the first one lasted well over a year.

Original Review
The bulbs came in today and arrived in perfect condition. One of the first things I checked was the voltage rating and saw the ones I got were rated for 130 volts. In my opinion this is good as the higher rating usually means a little longer service life as most of us have circuits that operate at 120 to 125 volts. This produces lower than the design load and can increase service life.

The box of bulbs I received actually contined 25 bulbs, five rows in each direction. The extra bulb is welcome and with the 130 volt rating I hope the bulbs will last a long time.

As my experience factor increases I will report if I notice anything of interest developing regarding these bulbs.

A stylish LED table lamp that with a couple small tweaks would be a 5-star item.  Review is written to suggest very modest design changes.

The lamp itself is shiny black plastic with various modes and adjustments.  Everything is controlled with touch, no knobs or clicking buttons.  You're able to control the temperature of the lighting, dimming, and on/off timer, as well as a nightlight function.  There's a USB charge outlet as well.  All work well, 5/5 stars.

Here are the changes I'd suggest:  1) Add a very small LED indicator to the power on/off switch.  As it is, we walk into a dark room and fumble touch the lamp's base plate hoping to tap on the correct area to turn it on..  A small indicator would be fantastic.  2) Move the USB output, or mirror the USB output, to the front of the baseplate.
summary: Great desk lamp with some minor design changes would be 5/5 stars.

These fans are the most thoughtlessly engineered item I've seen in a long time.  Where to begin?
They are really only suitable for new construction. Other reviews have suggested that they are difficult to retrofit, but in fact, they CANNOT be properly installed at all unless it is done before the finish ceiling is installed around them.  It doesn't matter if you have attic access.  For proper install they must go in before the drywall because the various flanges prevent the fan from fitting through it's own hole!  Why would they do this?  It would have been so easy to design them otherwise.  It's very similar to the oversight with the knock-outs for wire strain relief, also noted by others -- if proper strain relief is installed in the top knock-out, the hatch cannot be closed.  Baffling!
And a few other issues to note: They're not that quiet; the listing claims the noise level is 0.6 sones, but mine are marked 0.8 sones, and even then they seem quite a bit louder than that, even before I've hooked up the duct.  The mounting flanges require a minimum 2x6 inch joist, won't work with a 2x4.  At the same time, if you opt for the adjustable mounting brackets instead, they are set so low in the housing that your finish ceiling can be a maximum of only 1/2 inch -- thicker drywall or planks or such are too thick.
CONCLUSION: this is a decent fan for the price but with some very specific mounting requirements for NEW construction only.

First, the gloves I received don't look exactly like the photo. They are a white/gray generic glove with no logo (fine with me) and the cuff is also solid white with brown edge.

They are listed as nitrile with a nylon shell, but the ones I received have a polyester shell. The polyester seems warmer and retains moisture more than the nylon gloves I had been used to from another brand.

The cuff rolls itself up really easily, and the fit is in my opinion loose for a large size glove. I was hoping they might shrink a bit in the wash, but they didn't. For fine dexterity work, I'd choose a medium.

Grip is good, but the nitrile is a little too sticky until it gets some dust/dirt on it.

I bought these because the price was great for a nitrile glove. I was amazed at the price of less than 2 dollars a pair.

I've only had them for a week or so, and I'm rotating through my first 3 pairs, so I can't say how well they hold up. So far durability seems fine.

I'm going to use these gloves, but once they wear out, I'm going to go back to my former brand of gloves. The quality and fit of the other brand is worth the higher cost.

reviewText:
This is a great device to monitor the charging system and now that I have it sure taken out a lot of guess works or taking the meter and make reading, especially the current reading isn't practical for meter and probes.  Plug it in and play around with the arrows and it will display PV voltage a great function which allow me to switch from DC charging when voltage below biased voltage for AC grid tie (for AC solar panel equipped with microinverter).  It will display battery's health = State Of Charge and temperature and many other useful displays and it is light up everytime the key is pressed so no need for a flashlight to read it in the dark.

It is pricey and I don't know how long will this device last but it will make your life better at this experiment stage.
summary: A great add on to the system

Just leave them a little low to check the drum to conveyor clearance .. mine was about perfect with the factory installed 80 grit belt.  I used two identical 4' levels as straight edges, then just bring up the tables to adjust and do final tightening.  Happy Sanding!

Second, I have tried to find this size at the big box stores and so often all they have is the corrugated paper ones that are so much more expensive and not necessary. We use these for our AC and they are filthy when we change them! They are cheap and you really get your money's worth in AC efficiency alone. One time when we had a lot going on and forgot to change the filter the water from the AC started leaking from our 3rd floor down to our 2nd floor bedroom because it was so over clogged. I have never forgotten to change the filter since, and it makes sense to just buy the package so that I always have them on hand (and it's a better price for the package anyway).

reviewText:
I found two of the 6 "bulbs" were working and that's all I needed. The thing I was disappointed with is that two of the six were also broken in their packaging. In both cases the small coils were damaged. One is broken so badly I'm not even going to try and power it up for fear of what might happen.

The thing that just doesn't makes sense about this is that they were packaged well; they come packaged two each per anti-static bag, the three bags are then packed into a printed paper-board box, then this was packed in a larger box which was secured to prevent the smaller box from rattling around. With it that well packaged I'm left to wonder whether these were broken when they were initially packed in the manufacturer's packaging.

I used them in some IKEA bookshelf light fixtures to replace the halogen bulbs and they look great if not a touch too bright. They also have a bit of a whine to them as well which is perceptible even with noise in the house. I think I'm going to need to find another solution, but for now these will do.

I love this night light.  I ordered it to use in my infant's bedroom and it is perfect.  When I need to go into the nursery in the middle of the night to change or feed her, I try to avoid bright lights that would bring her to an alert state so I was looking for something with a softer, red-based tone to avoid the blue light that is emitted from cell phones and computer screens.  Although the bulb that this light comes with is clear, I feel the Himalayan salt cover is a softer glow and I like the health benefits that Himalayan salt lamps provide.  The particular salt cover that my light came with isn't all that red, but it casts is nice and gentle light in the room.  The light itself is very high quality, as well.  I am impressed with the construction, the way it fits together, and it looks great in the room.  It's well made and the only thing that I would like even more is if it came with a dimmer switch or an adjustment switch to toggle between low, mid, and bright light.  It is quite heavy when put together, but the salt cover fits snugly on the base with a rubber-based fitting so I am not concerned that it will fall apart or break if bumped.  I also like the feature it has where it can be positioned horizontally or vertically.  The Himalayan salt cover measures 2 1/2" long and 2" in diameter.  I am including a few pictures so you can see the assembly and get an idea of how bright the light is in a dark room.  I received this product at a discount in exchange for a fair, unbiased review but would re-purchase and definitely recommend to others.

We have to weed eat some bad places and wearing safety glasses just isn't enough. I don't like getting hit in the face with sticks and rocks and sometimes worse. I usually wear a plastic shield which is a little bulky and fogs up too much but does offer good protection. The worse part about it is keeping it clean (although pledge cleans the plastic pretty good). This provides equally good protection and you can still breathe which is great as the plastic always made me feel like I was smothering. I do wish I could wear my ear muffs though so I could listen to my music while I'm weed eating but it's really not comfortable to do so. Since the shield is dark it's also a little hard to weed eat late in evening, or at least it is for me. It doesn't bother my husband as much. We have a swampy area we have to weed eat and if you get too low to ground you throw the water up in your face and the mesh doesn't hold it back. The plastic shield does although it gets so splattered you can't see after awhile anyway.  Overall, I think these are made very well and will last awhile and I will be using this shield from now on...well, except in the swamp and I plan on sending my husband down there.

I did a great deal of research on the FENIX company, as well as the PD35 TAC Flashlight.  Every review I read or came across, had nothing but fantastic things to say about this fantastic flashlight.  PD35 TAC Flashlight was mentioned in every review I read, or watched online. When compared to other brands even the negatives noted were not serious, and the "flashlight shined on in my mind".  I received the PD35 TAC this morning, (one day shipping and it was at my door at 7:00am - thank you Amazon!!), along with a Fenix AOF-S+ RED Filter, and the AOD-S Diffuser Tip. All items were exactly as described, and in perfect condition. This is not my first tactical light, and ordered it without the 18650 battery included, so first time buyers beware, you will need a battery and a charger for the 18650 cell. The nice part is that it will also function with two (2) CR-123 lithium cells that are easy to purchase at most stores that sell batteries, including your local quick store in the neighborhood, Wally World and many others.

Putting a charged 18650 into the unit, I was amazed.  The factory default setting is the Tactical mode which only allows the rear tail switch to operate the unit in three modes. Turbo 1000 Lumens, Low 80 Lumens, and a very aggressive disorienting Strobe at 1000 Lumens.  It was very intuitive to half press the tail switch and switch between the modes, and then be able to choose the setting you want in a very short learning curve time frame.  For my everyday carry needs I will keep the  PD35 TAC Flashlight  in the Tactical mode, giving me the true functionality I was looking for in the first place.  Evening's in the wood or on the lake I will switch to the Outdoor mode which is quite simple.  With the PD35 TAC Flashlight in Turbo 1000 Lumens, press and hold the stainless steel side button until the strobe function starts and then in about 2 seconds the light will flash two (2) times. when that occurs you are now in Outdoor mode and have 5 brightness levels to choose from or cycle through as well as the strobe function.  The rear tail switch will turn the PD35 TAC Flashlight on and off, and retain the setting that you leave it in when you turn the light back on.  No need to cycle through all of the brightness settings again and again.  Getting back to the Tactical mode is as simple as holding the side button in for two seconds or so with the light on, and allowing the light to flash two (2) times again.  You are now back in the Tactical mode, and only tail switch operations are recognized.  Truly a great light, that I feel will last many years, and seems to be built tough and trouble fee, ( 5 Year Warranty from Fenix). The PD35 TAC Flashlight came with a nylon belt holster, wrist lanyard, spare o ring, and a replacement rubber tail switch cover.

I am already planning my next Fenix  PD35 TAC Flashlight purchase, this time along with the Fenix AER01/02 remote pressure switch, and the Fenix ALG rail mount to attach the  PD35 TAC to my hunting rifle.  I will have to keep testing the light for the next few weeks to see how its performance holds up in real life situations outside of the house.
summary: Impressive  PD35 TAC Flashlight right out of the box !!

reviewText: I've used a Festool in the past in a shop that I worked for and liked the things it could do and the accuracy that it could do them with.  When it came time for me to get a machine of my own, however, the Festool was out of my price range.  I bought the Makita and haven't regretted it.  I don't really use it all that often but when I do, I am impressed with its power and smoothness.  I initially got it with a 55" guide rail and in combination, they work very well.  I've just ordered another 55" rail and the Festool connector so I'll be able to rip panels into more manageable pieces (I've got a small shop and a small table saw).  Even though it takes a little time to set things up, the tool leaves a fine, splinter-free cut that makes it worth it.  I have yet to try all the things the saw might be capable of but I'm confident that it will do them as well as the right angle crosscuts.  As others have mentioned, the cord is a little short and the vacuum port does swivel (something that can probably be easily corrected) but they are minor issues.  All-in-all, a really nice tool and I'm pleased to have it in my collection.

Very nice light, small, neat and efficient, with a fit almost anywhere profile.  The light produced is about equivalent to a 75W candescent bulb.
However the leads are too short, which complicates the installation of the unit.  There is no junction box attached to the unit to connect and house the wires.  Therefore you need to add a junction box for the connection to the power line.  To connect the light to the 120 line requires more time because the wire from the transformer is so short. This complicates what should / could be much easier if the wire was just a couple of inches longer.
Typically recessed lighting units come with a junction box attached for the electrical connection.  This unit does not and it complicates the installation.
Personally, I would like to see the light sold with the transformer sold separately.  Then select a transformer to accommodate the total number of lights on that line.  This way there would be low voltage wiring between each light fixture, which lowers the cost of installation and increases the speed of installation.

I have had the RAT-1 for about a year now and although I do not carry it every day I love it!  I'm not going to get long-winded as I basically agree with 95% of the detailed info already posted on this great product. I will give you a few personal impressions.... It is razor sharp and made of a great/reliable and easy to sharpen steel.  I have not had to touch up the edge yet. I prefer the non-serrated blades although I have a few that are in my EDC collection.  My tastes include Spyderco, Kershaw, Gerber, Camillus, Ontario and Ka Bar mostly.  I look for blades that are an outstanding value overall and can do so with out spending $100.  I buy blades for a specific purpose/use.  This is a stout blade, a true working knife!  It is a bit heavy for summer EDC, but with heavy work clothes [construction trade] or with jeans in the winter/cooler months it is not a problem.  It is a good camp, pack, field unit or a handy blade to keep in your glove or tool box as long as you don't get pulled over in one of those "anti-everything" states/towns [i.e. the socialist town known as Chicago].  Drilled out liners would save a bit of weight.  But this weight also helps with balance and follow-through when cutting.  I paid about $26 shipped from another vender.  Hopefully Amazon will offer it again so more folks can buy this great value.  I was really happy that the lock-up and blade had a tight tolerance, sometimes even the higher cost blades need to be adjusted out of the box.

I have been replacing our track lighting million watts of lights with LED lights.  I think we probably have about 20 of them in the house from a 1980s kitchen.  I love a brightly lit kitchen.  I now like a kithcen that can;t be seen from outer space.  Put enough 9 watters in and...

I like the look of these.  Every single lightbulb in my kitchen is probably different at this point.

I also like a 6 pack.
Loud, irritating buzzing. The bulbs do put out a nice soft white light, but the noise is terrible.

Great bulbs:  OK price, great color temperature (match tungsten very well), good size for convention lamp sockets.  I'm using one of these and three LE 12W LED bulbs in a four-light Kitchen ceiling application where they face downward and replace four 100W conventional tungsten incandescent bulbs.  I inserted the LED bulbs one at a time to see how their light compared with the conventional 100W bulbs that they replaced.  To my surprise both the Muller and LE 12W LEDs match the 100W tunsten bulbs very well both in color and in brightness...in fact my wife and I think the LEDs appear a bit brighter than the 100 W tungsten bulbs they replace in this application.  In this application we've replaced 400W of tungsten bulbs with 48W of LEDs...a great saving, as it seems our kitchen lights are always on.

In separate engineering tests that I ran on the bulbs, I found that if you have an application that uses the light off the back side of the bulb (like an application with a rear reflector or a desk lamp where the bulb is facing up) then these bulbs are probably closer to matching conventional 60 or 75 watt bulbs.  Note that the Muller bulbs ARE dimmable...as is stated by the manufacturer, and we found that they dim very nicely with our conventional wall dimmer switch.  If you DON'T need dimmable bulbs, I found that the 12 Watt (75W) Warm White LED bulbs by LE were essentially identical to these Muller bulbs, BUT were much much less expensive.  I tried them side by side in our kitchen application and in my engineering tests.

In another test I'm using these Muller bulbs in an application with an on/off timer wired in series with the bulbs.  With conventional tungsten bulbs, the tungsten filament conducts electricity all the time to keep this timer powered even when the bulb is turned off.  This Muller LED performs the same function as it passes a low current even when it is turned off by the timer...in fact the bulb remains with a very very low glow when turned off by the timer (kind of like a weak night light).  So far the timer seems to be working normally, and the LED lights fully with the timer turns it on.  We'll see how it performs in the long run...if it works it's a great solution to our timer-light problem.  In the past we've been stuck with using incandescent bulbs with the timers as we really like the timer that simultaneously works as an real-time on-off switch when we want it and as a timer turning on the lights on and off when we're not at home.
summary: Great Dimmable LED bulbs for home Applications

First impression - 4 stars. This could improve as CRKT knives seem to grow on me as I use them.  I hope this one does as well. I want to love this knife -I'm a huge Ruger affectionado (SR45 & an LC9 are my bang bang EDC's) but my first impression is it's going to be a good friend but not a lover affair.

Indeed this is a big imposing folder.  Distinctive styling with the handle obviously designed to echo the picatinny rail used to mount scopes, sights or lasers on Ruger firearms.  Very clever.

The aluminum handle is robust but damn heavy. The center of balance is about a third of the way down the handle which has the effect of making the blade feel light but the overall package is again hefty...even heavier then my Espada large (see pics). Not a complaint but rather an observation. A plus is the weight make the butt of the handle a very effective blunt force weapon.

The blade is a thick serious slab of steel at 4.8 mm (compared to the cold steel Recons or Voyagers at 4mm) and it looks great. The stonewash finish is impeccable.  The shape is a drop point-ish spear point-ish hollow ground beauty.

The liner lock is confusing.  I'm sure CRKT knows what's it's doing but a liner lock for such a heavy blade just seems...well...a dainty choice. A knife this large should be able to take a big beating and liner locks just don't have the durability of a frame lock.  Simple physics. Conversely...and perhaps a rational...a liner lock does not snap shut once past the dentent like a frame lock does, so it does make that BIG blade bit safer to close for the less attentive (hand raised, as I've been seriously bitten and bloodied by the aggressive detent on a CS Voyager XL - I now have 9 1/2 fingerprints as a result) Risk vs reward I guess.  The liner lock itself is thick steel so I'm sure there are no worries when flicking.  Right CRKT?  I do like my10 fingers....

This death infictor does not use a pocket clip, which make sense considering the heft.  Rather, it has a nice codura sheath ( see pics).  I mount this upside down for quick deployment.  A knife this size, for me, is purely a self defense device and I carry it with that in mind.

Blade is razor sharp.  Thumbs posts are the size of large pushpins and as such make flipping open flippin' easy.

This knife is at a size and price point that bumps it into some very capable competition.  I think it will sell well with Ruger fans, less well with others.  I think the liner lock was a bad choice for this knife at this size though probably a good liability choice.  Should you buy it?  I think it will become a collector piece eventually especially for GUN collectors but as a tool I'm not sure.  I want to love you Go-N-Heavy.  You got a pretty face with a goofy Tony Soprano-esq name, but alas you may be answering a question that I'm not asking.

Time will tell.

As Reviewed by Yitzhak "Rabbi Steel" HaLevy

My a/c unit needs an odd-sized filter, 18x20, that I can never find in stores. Lucky for me, here they are in a convenient 6-pack on Amazon. On top of that, they are a high MERV rating, not a flimsy piece of junk that is a filter in name only. These things catch a lot of dust, pet hair and soot from our fireplace. We can smell the difference in the house. I've seen popular-size filters with this high a MERV rating in the store for upwards of $20 each, so the average price of $8 for the size I need, plus free shipping right to my door, I was more than pleased. I've already ordered a second batch, and will do so again.

I've taken a couple photos to show you all exactly how much dirt these things trap. We own cats, rabbits, and 2 fireplaces--lots of dust and hair in the air that killed our previous unit. These filters are catching it all.

reviewText:
I bought these quite awhile back figuring if I ever need them, I'll have them already.  I just cleaned out about half a hand full of hairs from the master bathroom sink.  That sort of thing isn't pleasant but it has to be done.  Hire a plumber... or do it yourself much cheaper.

I've gone through about 3 gallons of the heavy duty Liquid Plumber and that drain was always slow.  I unscrewed the sink stopper and poked the smaller size of the two included snakes down and up from the drain several times.  I was amazed at the amount of old hair there was in there.  Apparently it's been this way since the previous owner lived here.

Anyway, now I can fill the sink, leave both faucets wide open and in only a few seconds the sink will empty completely!  The problem is over.

Save your money.  Don't waste it on drain cleaners that don't really work anyway.  Buy a couple of the Turbo Snakes and be ready.
summary: There are a lot of things in this world that don't work... and, this "ain't" one of them!

reviewText:
This faucet is the real deal... In my recent remodels and upgrades I went with high-end faucets and other hardware (my "splurge" for doing a lot of the work myself), so I haven't bought or installed anything recently in this category - what I would call the "top tier of the middle of the road" category. (Confused? I know... basically it's priced higher than the average faucet at the big box stores, but not in the "specialty/luxury store" category.)

I was very pleasantly surprised when I took the faucet out of the box - it's heavy, solid, and substantial.  All the fittings were tight and clean, everything lined up perfectly, and the install was relatively simple. (I am NOT a plumber or handyman - just someone who likes to DIY... and also good at reading directions and watching videos on how to do it!)  Everything tightened up perfectly, fit as it should, and it works beautifully - and looks amazing!  Had I known Moen faucets were so great I would have gone with them for all my bath fixtures and saved at least a few hundred dollars for the same quality.
summary: Stunning, solid, runs beautifully, and a simple install

style.Style:: Door Pull Router Bit with 1/2-Inch Shank

reviewText:
This is one freaky MONSTER honking router bit!!! I'm sure my neighbors heard it a quarter mile away. So you better have a big solid honking router to handle it and you better be a man or at least a woman with some spiritual cojones.

I consider myself a fairly advanced woodworker... I've made a lot of cabinets... and some furniture like kitchen carts and coffee tables... hard maple... but I wouldn't say heirloom furniture just quite yet... I don't have a permanent shop, just my garage, so I guess I'm a weekend warrior that way. I'm sharing this just so you can compare your level to mine.

Anyway, I used this bit in my Bosch router mounted on my Bosch router table to cut lock miter joints for 7 newel posts made of 1" thick red oak...52" long...lots of joints! That isn't a nominal thickness, the actual true thickness is 1" and red oak is pretty hard and can be prone to being a little brittle as well when being cut so I consider this a good test. There are definitely harder woods, but I wasn't joining pine.

This was my first time using a lock miter bit and I think it has gone well. The joints fit without forcing and close tightly. I glued one this afternoon... will report back if it's not perfect but it looks pretty good from what I can see so far.

The wood was purchased rough sawn. I ran it through a thickness planer to get it down to my desired thickness, then cut to oversize length for the newel posts, then hit each piece with a jointer on one edge to get one nice straight square edge. Then cut to width on a table saw. Then the router comes in...

Regarding setup, I advise first time users (like me) to visit youtube and watch several different videos. Different people have different techniques. Setup blocks wouldn't work for me because of my stock thickness being non standard. The setup jigs seem to be made for 3/4 or 1/2 stock. I think even if you used a setup block you'd still be well advised to make test cuts to prove it's right. I just made cuts until it was right, making very small adjustments to height and depth until the joint was right. I'm planning to burnish or hit it with a small radius roundover to finish the edge anyway.. Once you get it right, DON'T MOVE THE DEPTH SETTING and don't move the fence until you mark the final position carefully so you can get back to it!

That said, I marked the fence position and then adjusted for a shallower depth of cut. I first tried about half depth, but had a lot of chatter. This bit chops out big hunks of wood and my shop vac wasn't clearing them from the cut zone very well so they were getting pulled back into the cutting bit and causing havoc!! I ended up making the miters in 4 passes. Yes, more time, but no chatter and nice smooth cuts. Trust me, you don't want ripple cuts! Easy does it. I found that having the shop vac at the top vacuum outlet helped to keep the cut zone clear, but the vast majority of the chips went DOWN inside the router table base. I had to clean it out every 6 cuts. That's more because of my router table than this bit, so no stars lost.

After each pass I moved the fence back a little. The final cut was about 1/8" of fence, which was pretty light. I wanted it that way to ensure a nice smooth finish cut. Try to make that finish cut in one smooth pass. Making a double pass will take off more than you want... don't do that. I tried it. I know. One smooth careful final pass. Perfecto!

After 7 newel posts in red oak, 52" long, 8 edges per post, 4 passes per edge... that's 7 x 4 x 8 x 52" = 11648" of cut... or 971 feet... nearly 0.2 miles... geez, I didn't realize it was that much! Anyway, the finalfinish cuts are smooth. Fast. Neato!

Good bit!

Bravo Freud!
summary: Excellent bit; BIG and AGGRESSIVE but setup not so complicated

This set is one of the most lust-worthy pieces of kit I have ever purchased for my personal toolkit. I am an electrician by trade and wanted to have a dedicated set of insulated drivers without taking up much space. This satisfies my need and more; the whole kit takes up next to no space and the cordura belt clip pouch it comes in really sets it off perfectly. Everyone I show this kit is blown away I only spent about $30 on it.

Amazing how much better these tools are than their American counterparts...rather sad actually; if Klein sold this exact set it would probably cost $150...I doubt I'll ever buy Klein tools again, since they are overpriced and outstripped in quality by most German tools.

Why is when I average the stars, I get 2.7, not 3.8, which you report as 4 stars?
Here I am wasting my time looking at something which is clearly a bad product, because it is falsely being reported as a good one.
At this moment, the stars and percentages are:
.36 x 5 + .09 x 3 + .09 x 2 + .46 x 1 = 2.7

And there are 4 stars lit up.

We are being tricked! We need more people to skew this down to where it belongs!
summary: Here I am wasting my time looking at something which is clearly a bad product, because it is falsely being reported as ...

reviewText: As a new home owner, I am constantly on the lookout for new tools. I've already run into a few sub-par examples where the grip doesn't grip or the locking slips. Fortunately, these Joint Pliers seem to function just as intended. Yes, they're big, but I can grip them closed with one hand unless it's open really wide. My only real issue are the red coverings. They're so slick, and I only have to wonder why they would be that way. I am a big fan of rough kind of grips which, I realize overtime will probably get smooth. Maybe this material is longer lasting which is fine. I would buy them again in a heart beat; my complaint, after all, is very minor. Oh, and they are made in the USA, assuming the label actually means which most think it means which is a plus for me anyway.

We bought for sets of these for around the house based on how it's set up. Each light is packaged separately. But the boxes are the same with just the color marked. We got all round lights, so it seems the company uses these for their square lights too. That isn't a big deal for me, just that one of my kids wanted square as it looks like that on the box.

The kids got to choose their colors for their room. As a note, the white are brighter at night than the remaining colors. So in hallways or common area where you need the light, you'll want to use the white lights.  In our kids' rooms, we did two night lights as they chose the color other than white. I have noticed that the light sensor works well; as some night lights turn on too easy and can be on if they are in a hallway on an overcast day. At this point, these seem to be better from that sensitivity.
summary: just that one of my kids wanted square as it looks like that on the box

All in all - unlike previous fan installation experiences - I actually ENJOYED putting this fan up!!! It looks great and works great - I couldn't be more pleased.  I'm buying three more to replace the rest of the small fans in my house - the Minka-Aire F518-WH is that good.

reviewText: Highly recommend. I used it on two smart light switches by Wemo. It fitted well. Smart wifi light switches generate some heat. The metallic cover would help to dissipate some of the heat. Furthermore, I was able to trigger lights remotely using Wemo or IFTTT app on my cell . Wemo light switch manufacturer does not recommend using metallic wall switch cover due to absorption of wifi signals. However, it worked well for me. This was probably because my modem/router was pretty close to the metallic wall cover.

I had 3 apartments to paint and usually only have a 1-2 hours to spare each session.  I do enjoy painting and I initially thought It's was a good idea to save money on paint tray liners.  What ends up happening is that you spend a lot of time scrapping paint off.  I ended up wrapping it with aluminum foil and tape instead of using a paint tray liner.

As a tray this might be usable with a 7-inch roller but if you are using a 9-inch it isn't comfortably wide enough with some frames (like the Wooster Brush R017-9, the roller is a tight fit) and isn't deep enough and i find myself manually using a brush a lot to apply the paint onto the roller.

My next paint tray would be meant for 11-inch rollers and deeper.
summary: Gimmick - pass, get a wider and deeper one.

reviewText:
Bought these for my daughter's room, she loved them but unfortunately 1/3 of the lights don't turn on anymore, and another 1/3 of the lights flicker slightly when the cord is touched.  They worked for 6 months.

Edit:  Seller contacted me only days after my review was posted.  I emailed them a short video showing the malfunction and they immediately shipped me a replacement.  I'll give 5 Stars to anyone who stands behind their product like that.

I used these to upgrade the plastic clips that have been in the cabinets for over a decade. The plastic clips essentially fell apart when I attempted to remove them. There were 2 cabinets with clips that look identical to these. They seem to be intact and holding up perfectly. Only time will tell, but from my initial use of them I will give them 5 stars for quality.
